src_content.description: β-D-glucose residues connected through 1-3 glycosidic bonds, commonly found in oligoglucosides that are components of cell wall polysaccharides.
α-L-guluronic acid residues connected through 1-4 glycosidic linkages, forming a structural unit commonly found in alginate polysaccharides produced by brown seaweed.
β-D-mannuronic acid residues connected through 1-4 glycosidic linkages, commonly found as a structural component in alginate polysaccharides produced by brown seaweed.
β-D-galactose residues connected through 1-6 glycosidic bonds, commonly present as side chains in branched galactan structures.
β-D-glucose residues linked via 1-6 glycosidic bonds, commonly found in oligoglucosides released from cell walls by endo-glucanases.

The 2-6-branch of complex N-glycans refers to the α1-6 core mannose that is substituted at both the 2 and 6 positions, bearing GlcNAcβ1-6 and GlcNAcβ1-2 antennae. This structure typically features a Galβ1-4GlcNAcβ1-2(Galβ1-4GlcNAcβ1-6)Manα1-R motif, representing a common branching pattern in complex N-glycans.

2′-fucosyllactose is a human milk oligosaccharide composed of lactose with an α1-2-linked fucose attached to the galactose residue. It is known to inhibit pathogen binding by mimicking host cell surface receptors.
A galactose residue that is modified by sulfation at the 3-O position. This modification is recognized as a ligand involved in the clearance of pituitary hormones from the bloodstream.

A glucosamine residue in heparin or heparan sulfate that is N-sulfated, 6-O-sulfated, and further modified by 3-O-sulfation. This specific modification, known as 3-O-sulfated GlcNS6S, is critical for antithrombin–heparin interaction and is also recognized by certain viruses, highlighting its functional significance in biological processes.

A structural variant of chondroitin sulfate glycosaminoglycan characterized by sulfation of the N-acetylgalactosamine residues at the 4-position, which is relevant to glycosaminoglycan-protein interactions.

Glucosamine residues within heparan sulfate chains that are sulfated at the 6-O position. These residues are subject to modification by endosulfatases (SULFs), which can alter their sulfation status and influence the biological properties of the glycan chain.

6-sulfo-sialyl Lewis X (6-sulfo-SLex) is a sialyl Lewis X (LeX) glycan motif that is further modified by sulfation at the 6-position of the N-acetylglucosamine. As a high-affinity L-selectin ligand (often on mucin-type glycoconjugates), it promotes leukocyte rolling and homing at high endothelial venules and can influence cell–cell interactions in inflammation and cancer.)

src_content.evidence: The cognate ligands for L-selectin possess the unusual sulfated tetrasaccharide epitope 6-sulfo sialyl Lewis x (Siaalpha2-->3Galbeta1-->4[Fucalpha1-->3][SO(3)-->6]GlcNAc).[PMID:11331001]

function.content: lymphocyte homing

src_content.description: 6′-sulfo-sialyl Lewis X (6′-sulfo-SLex) is a sialyl Lewis X (SLex) glycan motif that is further modified by sulfation at the 6′ position of the galactose residue. It serves as a recognition ligand for selectins and Siglecs, guiding cell to cell interactions in the immune system and shaping inflammatory responses at mucosal surfaces.

src_content.definition: A branched amino tetrasaccharide comprised of a trisaccharide chain of N-acetyl-α-neuraminic acid, 6-O-sulfo-β-D-glactose and N-acetyl-β-D-glucosamine residues linked sequentially (2→3) and (1→4), to the GlcNAC residue of which is also linked (1→3) an α-L-fucose residue.[CHEBI:71558]
src_content.evidence: Studies using sulfotransferase-deficient mice showed that 6-sulfo sialyl Lewis X (6-sulfo sLe(x)), a major ligand for L-selectin that is expressed on the high endothelial venules (HEVs), plays critical roles in lymphocyte homing to the peripheral lymph nodes.[PMID:2288521]

function.content: lymphocyte homing

src_content.description: Sialic acids that are modified by acetylation at the 9-hydroxyl position. This modification can influence recognition by sialic acid-binding proteins, such as CD22.

src_content.definition: N-acetyl-9-O-acetyl-alpha-neuraminic acid is a member of the class of N-acetylneuraminic acids that is alpha-neuraminic acid which has acetylated on N-5 and O-9. It has functional parent alpha-neuraminic acid.[CHEBI:84941]
src_content.evidence: Levels of 9-O-acetyl sialic acid provide a distinct way to define progenitors and thus facilitate the study of hematopoietic differentiation.[PMID:31411667]

src_content.description: ABO blood group antigens are terminal glycan structures found on glycoproteins and glycolipids that define the A, B, and H blood group types. These glycans serve as receptors for certain viruses and are specifically recognized by lectins and antibodies, playing a key role in blood group determination and immune recognition.

A glycan structure that is attached to a membrane through an alkylacylphosphatidylinositol anchor. This glycan may contain components such as nonacetylated glucosamine, mannose, galactofuranose, and 2-aminoethylphosphonate.
Amylopectin is a branched polysaccharide consisting of α-1,4-linked D-glucose units with α-1,6-linked branch points. It is one of the two major components of starch.

Apiogalacturonan is a class of plant cell wall pectic polysaccharides characterized by a galacturonic acid backbone with β-D-apiose (Apif) and apiobiose residues attached to the O-2 position of some backbone residues. These polysaccharides are found in duckweeds and seagrasses.

Arabinoglucuronoxylan (AGX) is a type of plant cell wall hemicellulose found in gymnosperms, characterized by a xylan backbone that is substituted with both methylglucuronic acid (MeGlcpA) and arabinofuranose (Araf) residues.

A family of glycosphingolipids (GSLs) characteristic of invertebrates, especially arthropods, built on a mactosylceramide core (Manβ1-4Glcβ-ceramide) that may contain multiple N-acetylglucosamine residues and is often further modified with galactose, fucose, glucuronic acid, phosphoethanolamine, or phosphorylcholine.

a-series gangliosides are a class of glycosphingolipids characterized by the presence of a single sialic acid residue attached to the inner galactose of the lactosylceramide core. They are biosynthesized through the addition of sialic acid to GM3 and cannot be directly converted to b-series gangliosides by sialyltransferases.

Asialo-GM1, also known as GA1, is a neutral ganglioside of the ganglio-series with the structure Galβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer. It is formed by extending lactosylceramide with GalNAc (β1-4) followed by Gal (β1-3).

src_content.evidence: We compared the lateral structure of giant unilamellar vesicles (GUVs) composed of three pseudo binary mixtures of different glycosphingolipid (GSL), i.e. sulfatide, asialo-GM1 or GM1, with POPC.[PMID:29106974]

src_content.description: Asialo-GM1, also known as GA1, is a neutral ganglioside of the ganglio-series with the structure Galβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer. It is formed by extending lactosylceramide with GalNAc (β1-4) followed by Gal (β1-3).

N-linked glycans with a complex-type structure characterized by two antennae (branches) extending from the core. These glycans are commonly found on glycoproteins and are known for their specific lectin binding properties.

src_content.definition: A complex N-glycan that has two branches attached to the non-reducing terminal Man residues of the trimannosyl core. . Each branch is initiated with a GlcNAc and can be exteneded or capped with HexNAc, deoxyHex, Hex, or sialic acid residues. [CHEBI:156251]
src_content.evidence: The crystal structure of Pterocarpus angolensis lectin is determined in its ligand-free state, in complex with the fucosylated biantennary complex type decasaccharide NA2F, and in complex with a series of smaller oligosaccharide constituents of NA2F.[PMID:16704415]

src_content.description: Biantennary N-glycans are N-linked glycans characterized by two antennae (branches) extending from the core pentasaccharide structure. These branches can be further modified by the addition of sugars such as galactose, sialic acid, or fucose.

src_content.definition: Type of N-linked glycan in which two antenna are present on the trimannosyl core, each initiated by GlcNAc additions catalyzed by position-specific N-acetylglucosaminyltransferases (GlcNAcTs). Each antenna can be exteneded or capped with HexNAc, deoxyHex, Hex, or sialic acid residues. [Essentials of Glycobiology:Glossary]
src_content.evidence: We found an efficient isopropylidenation reaction that selectively protects the terminal Gal-3,4-OH of a biantennary complex-type nonasaccharide isolated from a natural source.[PMID:29249147]

src_content.description: A complex-type N-glycan structure that contains a bisecting N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) residue attached via β1-4 linkage to the core mannose of N-glycans. This modification is typically introduced by the enzyme MGAT3.
A β1-4-linked N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) residue attached to the core mannose of N-glycans, formed by the action of N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase III (MGAT3).

src_content.definition: The bisecting GlcNAc is a modification of hybrid or complex N-linked glycans in which a single GlcNAc is added to the 3 position of the b-linked Man found in the trimannosyl core structure. The modification is catalyzed by beta 1,4-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase III (GlcNAcT-III) or MGAT3 (E.C. 2.4.1.144). The addition of a bisecting GlcNAc on a hybrid or trimmed hybrid glycan prevents the subsequent action of N-glycan branching glycosyltransferases GlcNAcT-IV and GlcNAcT-V, but GlcNAcT3 can add a bisecting GlcNAc to the products of these enzymes. [PMID: 22476631]
src_content.evidence: The presence of a bisecting GlcNAc and the occurrence of alpha 2-6-linked Neu5Ac in the most abundant N-glycans, are new features for hCG-beta.[PMID:1374031]

function.content: The bisecting GlcNAc of N-glycans regulates cellular signaling and tumor progression through modulating N-glycan/galectin interactions.[PMID: 22476631]Inhibits growth factor signaling and retards mammary tumor progression[PMID: 20395209]Integrin-mediated cell adhesion [PMID: 20816221]Important in fertilization and fetal development, neuritogenesis, immune tolerance, immunoglobulin G (IgG)

src_content.description: A structural feature in certain fungal N-glycans where an N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is attached in an α1-4 linkage to the β-mannose core, distinct from the common β1-4-linked bisecting GlcNAc in mammals.

The blood group A determinant is a glycan structure found on the surface of red blood cells that defines blood group A. It is formed by the terminal addition of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to the H antigen, a reaction catalyzed by A-transferase. This structure is a key component in distinguishing blood group A from other blood groups.

src_content.definition: A branched amino trisaccharide consisting of β-D-galactose having an α-L-fucosyl residue at the 2-position and an N-acetyl-α-D-galactosaminyl residue at the 3-position.[CHEBI:61012]
src_content.evidence: A readily detectable carbohydrate in the urine of two siblings with neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis was found to be the blood group A trisaccharide.[PMID:7249368]

src_content.description: A class of glycan epitopes found on glycoproteins and glycolipids that determine human blood groups, including the A, B, O(H), and other antigens.

The blood group B determinant is a specific glycan epitope, typically Galα1-3(Fucα1-2)Gal-R, present on the surface of red blood cells, glycoproteins, and glycolipids. It defines the blood group B antigen in humans and is formed by the terminal addition of galactose to the H antigen, catalyzed by B-transferase. This structure is recognized by specific antibodies and lectins, and is a key determinant in blood group typing.

The blood group H determinant is a glycan antigen and epitope characterized by the presence of an α1-2-linked fucose residue, synthesized by α1-2 fucosyltransferase (FucT). It is formed by the addition of α1-2-linked fucose to the terminal galactose of a type 1 unit (Galβ1-3GlcNAc), resulting in the structure Fucα1-2Galβ1-3GlcNAc. This determinant serves as a precursor for ABO blood group antigens.

exact_synonyms: type 1 blood group H core trisaccharide
src_content.description: A core trisaccharide glycan structure with the sequence Fucα1-2Galβ1-3GlcNAc, characteristic of the type 1 blood group H antigen. This structure can serve as a core that may be further substituted or capped in various glycan contexts.

src_content.evidence: Blood group H type 1 [Fuc alpha (1,2)Gal beta (1,3)GlcNAc beta-->] is known as the precursor structure of the blood group determinant, Lewis b [Fuc alpha (1,2)Gal beta (1,3)(Fuc alpha (1,4))GlcNAc beta-->].[PMID:7718581]

src_content.description: An N-linked glycan characterized by a branched structure, which can carry ABO(H) antigens and poly-LacNAc extensions.

b-series gangliosides are a class of glycosphingolipids characterized by the presence of two sialic acid residues attached to the inner galactose. Examples include GD3 and GT1b. These structures are formed through the action of sialyltransferases during glycosphingolipid biosynthesis.

Callose is a plant and fungal polysaccharide composed primarily of β-1,3-linked glucose residues, sometimes featuring β-1,6 branches. It plays important roles in cell wall structure and is involved in defense responses.
Cellobiose is a disaccharide composed of two β-1,4-linked glucose residues and serves as the repeating unit of cellulose.

Cellulose is a linear polysaccharide made up of β-1,4-linked glucose units. It serves as the primary structural component of plant cell walls and is one of the most abundant biopolymers found in nature.

Chitin is a linear polymer composed of β-D-N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) residues linked via β(1→4) glycosidic bonds. It forms the structural backbone of invertebrate exoskeletons and fungal cell walls, providing strength and rigidity.

Chitobiose is a disaccharide composed of two β(1→4)-linked N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) units, forming the core structure of N-glycans. In some biological contexts, this chitobiose core can be elongated by additional monosaccharides, particularly in cases involving defects in mannosyltransferase activity or in certain parasitic organisms, resulting in extended chitobiose motifs.

Chondroitin is a glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetylgalactosamine and glucuronic acid. These units can be further modified by sulfation and epimerization. Chondroitin serves as the backbone for chondroitin sulfate and related structures.

Chondroitin sulfate A is a subtype of chondroitin sulfate glycosaminoglycan characterized by repeating disaccharide units containing glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine, with sulfation typically occurring at the 4-position of the N-acetylgalactosamine residue.

Chondroitin sulfate B, also known as dermatan sulfate, is a glycosaminoglycan characterized by the presence of iduronic acid–containing disaccharide units. It is formed by the epimerization of glucuronic acid in chondroitin sulfate chains.

Chondroitin sulfate C is a subtype of chondroitin sulfate glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units containing glucuronic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine, with sulfation typically occurring at the 6-position of the N-acetylgalactosamine residue.

Chondroitin sulfate is a sulfated glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetylgalactosamine and glucuronic acid, with variable sulfation patterns. It commonly occurs as chains covalently attached to proteoglycans and can be found as oligosaccharide segments (typically 4–20 residues) derived from or mimicking portions of the full polysaccharide.

src_content.definition: Any of a class of 10‚Äî60 kDa glycosaminoglycan sulfates, widely distributed in cartilage and other mammalian connective tissues.[CHEBI:37397]
src_content.evidence: The industrial production of chondroitin sulfate (CS) uses animal tissue sources as raw material derived from different terrestrial or marine species of animals.[PMID: 31013685]

src_content.description: A glycan modification in which a mannose residue is attached through a carbon-carbon (C-glycosidic) bond, most commonly found on tryptophan residues within thrombospondin type 1 repeats (TSRs) and certain complement proteins.

Complex gangliosides are gangliosides with multiple glycan extensions beyond the simple monosialylated core, often containing additional sialic acid and N-acetylgalactosamine residues. They are synthesized by the sequential action of sialyltransferases and N-acetylgalactosaminyltransferases.

Complex glycans are oligosaccharides with branched and extended structures, typically referring to mature N-glycans or O-glycans that have undergone extensive processing and addition of various sugars beyond the core. These structures often feature complex sugar chains, such as sialylated, sulfated, glucuronylated, or zwitterionic modifications, and include both complex N-glycans and other complex-type glycans.

Complex glycolipids are glycolipids that possess oligosaccharide chains longer or more branched than those found in simple mono- or disaccharide glycolipids. They are synthesized from precursors like glucosylceramide through additional glycosylation steps.

Complex O-glycans are O-glycans with extended and branched structures, typically formed by the sequential addition of monosaccharides to an initial N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) linked to serine or threonine residues of proteins. These glycans are highly diverse and are commonly found on mucins and other glycoproteins.

Complex-type N-glycans are a class of N-linked glycans characterized by the addition of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) to the core mannose residues, followed by further branching and elongation with sugars such as galactose, sialic acid, and fucose. These glycans are typically multiantennary and highly branched, formed after mannose trimming in the Golgi apparatus and subsequent action of glycosyltransferases. Their biosynthesis involves full processing of the GlcNAcMan5GlcNAc2 intermediate, and they are commonly found on glycoproteins in higher eukaryotes.

src_content.definition: Type of N-linked glycan in which at least two antenna are present on the trimannosyl core, each initiated by GlcNAc additions catalyzed by position-specific N-acetylglucosaminyltransferases (GlcNAcTs). Each antenna can be exteneded or capped with HexNAc, deoxyHex, Hex, or sialic acid residues.
src_content.evidence: In this study, 32 new complex-type glycans are characterized containing the Le(x), Le(Y), and sialyl-Le(x) determinants, the bloodgroup A and H antigens, as well as the ALe(Y) determinant.[PMID:10988252]

function.content: Involved in protein stability.

src_content.description: Complex-type N-glycans that are modified by the addition of sialic acid residues at the terminal positions of their branches. These sialylated structures contribute to a negative charge, play roles in biological recognition, and are often used to enhance the circulatory half-life and alter the biodistribution of glycoproteins.

src_content.definition: Complex N-linked glycan that have added GlcNAc residues at both the α-3 and α-6 mannose sites and do not contain mannose residues apart from the core structure but with sialic acid residues.
src_content.evidence: By using 1H-NMR spectroscopy we were able to establish that our product contains a single N-linked biantennary , fully sialylated complex-type oligosaccharide , typical of human hepatomas.[PMID:1694115]

function.content: enhance the signaling activity of soluble intercellular adhesion molecule-1 in mouse astrocytes [PMID: 15201278] Appears in IgG-Fc.

src_content.description: The core 1 O-glycan, also known as Galβ1-3GalNAcα1-O-Ser/Thr, is a disaccharide structure that forms the basic core of mucin-type O-glycans in vertebrates and some invertebrates. It consists of a galactose β1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine α-linked to serine or threonine residues on proteins. This structure is the most common O-GalNAc glycan, generated by the enzyme C1GALT1 (T-synthase), and serves as a precursor for further elongation and modification, including sialylation and sulfation, in O-glycosylation.

src_content.evidence: O-glycans are initiated by the addition of GalNAc to serine or threonine (via the ppGalNAcT family of glycosyltransferases), forming the Tn antigen (GalNAcα-O-Ser/Thr), which is used to generate the core 1 structure (Galβ1,3GalNAcα-O-Ser/Thr) on which most complex and branched O-glycans are derived. [PMID:31645367]

src_content.description: Core 2 O-glycan is a mucin-type O-GalNAc glycan structure formed by the addition of a GlcNAcβ1-6 branch to the GalNAc residue of core 1, resulting in the structure Galβ1-3(GlcNAcβ1-6)GalNAcα1-O-Ser/Thr. This structure is a major branch of O-GalNAc glycans, is more cell type–specific than core 1, and serves as a scaffold for further extension and modification, including the formation of selectin ligands.

src_content.definition: The trisaccharide β-D-Gal-(1→3)-[β-D-GlcNAc-(1→6)]-D-GalNAc with α configuration at the anomeric centre of the N-acetylglucosamine residue at the reducing end.[CHEBI:62158]
src_content.evidence: To investigate the biological roles of core 2 O-glycans, we produced and characterized mice deficient in one or more of the three known glycosyltransferases that generate core 2 O-glycans (C2GnT1, C2GnT2, and C2GnT3).[PMID: 19349303]

src_content.description: A mucin-type O-glycan structure characterized by the addition of GlcNAcβ1-3 to GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr, resulting in the structure GlcNAcβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr.

src_content.definition: An amino disaccharide comprising an N-acetyl-β-D-glucosamine residue linked (1→3) to an N-acetyl-β-D-galactosamine residue at the reducing end.[CHEBI:71344]
src_content.evidence: Mechanically, we revealed that mucin-type core 3 O-glycan was synthesized at the membrane-tethered MUC1 N terminus because of core 3 synthase expression in colon cancer cells.[PMID: 28745318]

src_content.description: Core 4 O-GalNAc glycan is a mucin-type O-glycan structure where the core 3 structure (GlcNAcβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr) is further branched by the addition of a GlcNAc residue via a β1-6 linkage, resulting in the structure GlcNAcβ1-6(GlcNAcβ1-3)GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr.

src_content.definition: A branched amino trisaccharide comprising an N -acetyl-α-D-galactosamine residue at the reducing end, to which are (1→3)- and (1→6)-linked two N -acetyl-α-D-glucosamine residues.[CHEBI:71341]
src_content.evidence: The results confirm the predicted existence of a beta1,6GlcNAc-transferase that functions in both core 2 and core 4 O-glycan branch formation.[PMID: 9988682]

src_content.description: A fucose residue attached in α1-6 linkage to the innermost GlcNAc of N-glycans, serving as a key structural feature that influences glycan function.

src_content.definition: Modification of the N-glycan core structure with fucose moiety attached at the innermost GlcNAc by FUT8 enzyme. Core Fuc is found on paucimannose, hybrid and complex type N-glycans. [https://doi.org/10.1016/bs.acr.2014.11.006].
src_content.evidence: The approach was validated for selective capture and analysis of core fucosylated N-glycans present in complex glycan mixtures derived from mammalian serum IgG.[PMID:27678371]

function.content: Required for signaling through TCR
VGF, PDGFr, and EGFr and TGFbeta receptor dysregulation in Fut8 KO mice
IgG-Fcg receptor interactions destabilized by core Fuc

src_content.description: Core M1 O-mannose glycan is one of the three main core structures (M1–M3) of O-mannose glycans, characterized by the addition of a single N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) in β1-2 linkage to a protein-linked mannose. This core structure is generated by the action of POMGNT1 and can be further extended by various glycosyltransferases, representing a specific and conserved oligosaccharide core in O-mannosylation.

Core M2 O-mannose glycan is a type of O-mannose glycan core structure characterized by the addition of two N-acetylglucosamines (GlcNAc) to a protein-linked mannose via β1-2 and β1-6 linkages. This structure is formed from core M1 through the action of MGAT5B and can be further extended by various glycosyltransferases.

The core M3 O-mannose glycan is one of the three main core structures (M1–M3) of O-mannose glycans, representing a specific conserved oligosaccharide core found on mammalian α-dystroglycan. It serves as a priming substrate for the addition of repeating disaccharide units (Xyl-α3-GlcA-β3-)n, a process catalyzed by the LARGE1 or LARGE2 glycosyltransferases.
A class of gangliosides characterized by the presence of three sialic acid residues attached to the glycan core, including structures such as GT3 and its derivatives.

sources.src_lbl: C-Series gangliosides oligosaccharide / hemato- or ganglio-type

src_content.description: Cyclic β1-2 glucans are polysaccharides consisting of 17–25 glucose units connected by β1-2 linkages. They are synthesized by certain bacteria, such as Agrobacterium.

Dermatan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) consisting of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetylgalactosamine and iduronic acid, which is formed by epimerization of glucuronic acid. The chain is modified by O-sulfation and is typically found as a sulfated polysaccharide component of proteoglycans.

src_content.definition: Any of a group of glycosaminoglycans with repeating units consisting of variously sulfated β1→4-linked L-iduronyl-(α1→3)-N-acetyl-D-galactosamine units.[CHEBI:18376]
src_content.evidence: By utilizing sophisticated separation methods followed by compositional analysis, domain mapping, and tandem mass spectrometry coupled with analysis by a modified genetic algorithm approach, the structural motif for the decorin dermatan sulfate chain was determined.[PMID:29111696]

function.content: Wound healing
maintain the structure of the dermis.

src_content.description: Dextran is a class of polysaccharides composed primarily of α(1→6)-linked D-glucose units with occasional α(1→3) branches, and is commonly produced by certain bacteria.
Di-N-acetylbacillosamine (diNAcBac) is a bacterial monosaccharide containing two N-acetyl groups, and is commonly found at the reducing end of certain bacterial N-linked oligosaccharides.
A glycan motif composed of the Lewis a antigen with two sialic acid residues attached. It is present on colonic epithelial cells and its expression is altered in colon cancer.

src_content.definition: Disialyl Lewis is a sialyl Lewis a with an additional sialic acid attached at the C-6 position of penultimate GlcNAc. [PMID:15231659]
src_content.evidence: Biosynthesis of disialyl Lewis a (Lea) was analyzed using previously cloned ST6GalNAc V and ST6GalNAc VI, which were responsible for the synthesis of alpha-series gangliosides.[PMID:12668675]

function.content: The 2-3,2-6 disialyl Lea determinant on epithelial cells may play a role in protecting normal epithelial cells.

disease_association.content: Mucin antigen carrying 2-3 sialylated Le a antigen or 2-3, 2-6 disialylated Lc4 antigen in cancer patients had the lowest carbohydrate/protein ratio. Thus, the carbohydrate/protein ratio in the type 1 chain mucin antigens in sera of normal subjects is higher than that in sera of cancer patients.

src_content.description: An extended core-1 O-glycan is a core-1 O-glycan (Galβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr) that is further elongated by the addition of extra monosaccharides, such as in the biosynthesis of sulfated selectin ligands.

Fructans are storage polysaccharides made primarily of fructose units. They are commonly found in green plants, where they are stored in vacuoles and serve as energy reserves. Fructans may also contribute to plant protection against abiotic stress.

Fucoidans are sulfated polysaccharides mainly composed of fucose residues, typically featuring alternating 1-3 and 1-4 linkages. They are isolated from brown algae and are recognized for their diverse biological activities.

Fucosylated glycans are glycans that contain fucose residues, typically attached through α1-2, α1-3, or α1-4 linkages. These structures play important roles in biological processes such as host-pathogen interactions and cell signaling.
N-glycans that are modified by the addition of fucose residues. The presence of fucose can influence various biological processes, including neural development and function.

src_content.definition: The fucose from GDP-fucose is transferred to N-linked glycans.
src_content.evidence: Haptoglobin , an acute phase protein , has four potential N-glycosylation sites , although it remains unknown which site is responsible for the change in fucosylated N-glycans.[PMID:18214858]

src_content.description: A disaccharide composed of fucose linked α1-2 to galactose. This motif is commonly found as a terminal structure on host epithelial glycoconjugates, with its expression regulated by bacterial exposure and fucosyltransferase activity.

A complex-type N-glycan that lacks galactose residues on its antennae (agalactosylated), typically featuring a core Man3GlcNAc2 structure with two terminal GlcNAc residues. This structure is commonly found on glycoproteins and is recognized by mannose-binding proteins.
afucosylated agalactosylated biantennary N-glycan

Galabiose is a disaccharide composed of two galactose residues linked by an alpha1-4 glycosidic bond (Galα1-4Gal). It serves as a recognition motif for certain bacterial toxins and adhesins, and is found in glycolipids and glycoproteins, including as part of glycosphingolipids where it can be linked to ceramide. Galabiose-containing structures are present in the large intestine epithelium and function as receptors for specific pathogens.
A polysaccharide composed primarily of galactose residues, commonly found in fungal and plant cell walls.

Galactolipids are a class of glycolipids characterized by one or more galactose residues attached to a lipid moiety. They are commonly found in plant membranes and play important roles in membrane structure and function.
A polysaccharide composed of a mannose backbone with galactose side chains, commonly found in plant and fungal cell walls.
A branch of an N-glycan that ends with a galactose residue, typically in a β1-4 linkage to N-acetylglucosamine.

Galactosylceramide is a glycosphingolipid composed of a ceramide backbone with a single galactose residue β-linked to it. It is predominantly found in the nervous system, especially in brain and myelin lipids of deuterostome animals.

src_content.evidence: Galactosylceramide improved behavioral, neuropathological, and biochemical parameters in Cln3 Cln3 Δex7/8 mice, paving the way for effective therapy for CLN3 disease and use of serum ceramide as a potential biomarker to track impact of therapies.[PMID:31393621]

src_content.description: A disaccharide composed of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) α1-3 linked to galactose. This structure is found in blood group A antigens and certain glycolipids.

This is a trisaccharide fragment found in the Campylobacter jejuni N-glycan heptasaccharide, composed of GalNAcα1-4GalNAcα1-3-diNAcBac, where diNAcBac refers to 2,4-diacetamido-2,4,6-trideoxyglucopyranose.
A disaccharide composed of two N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues linked via an α1-4 glycosidic bond; it is a component of the Campylobacter jejuni N-glycan heptasaccharide.
A disaccharide composed of galactose alpha1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine, commonly found as a terminal structure in mucin-type O-glycans.
A disaccharide composed of two galactose residues connected by an alpha1-3 glycosidic bond. This structure is found as a capping motif on certain core trisaccharides in glycan structures.

A trisaccharide composed of galactose alpha1-3 linked to galactose beta1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine. This structure is a common terminal motif in many mammalian glycans but is notably absent in Old World primates.
A disaccharide composed of galactose linked alpha1-3 to glucose (alpha anomer). It can be found as a capping structure on certain core trisaccharides.
A trisaccharide motif composed of galactose β1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine, which is β1-4 linked to galactose. This structure is found as a component of gangliosides GM1b and GA1.

This tetrasaccharide motif consists of galactose β1-3 linked to N-acetylglucosamine, which is β1-3 linked to galactose, itself β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine. It is recognized by TRA-1-60 and TRA-1-81 antibodies as part of keratan sulfate–related antigens.

Ganglio-series glycosphingolipids are a class of glycosphingolipids defined by a specific core oligosaccharide structure (Galβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer), which can be further extended and sialylated to form gangliosides. These molecules are predominant in the mammalian brain and are classified based on the number of sialic acid residues and their migration order on thin-layer chromatography, such as GM (mono), GD (di), and GT (tri) series.

Gangliosides are glycosphingolipids (glycolipids) characterized by one or more sialic acid residues linked to an oligosaccharide chain, which is attached to a ceramide lipid. As a subclass of sialylated glycosphingolipids, they are abundant in the nervous system, particularly the brain, and function as important cell surface molecules involved in cell signaling, recognition, and as receptors for toxins and viruses.
Gb3, also known as the Pk antigen, is a type of glycosphingolipid containing a trisaccharide core structure with the sequence Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glc. It acts as a receptor for Shiga toxins.
The Pk antigen is a type of glycosphingolipid containing a trisaccharide core structure with the sequence Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glc. It acts as a receptor for Shiga toxins.

CD77 is a neutral glycosphingolipid consisting of Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer, also known as globotriaosylceramide (Gb3). It serves as a tumor-associated carbohydrate antigen, being highly enriched in certain cancers such as Burkitt’s lymphoma, and is recognized by specific monoclonal antibodies. As a component of lipid raft microdomains, CD77 influences cell signaling and can modulate tumor cell growth and invasion.
Gb4, also known as globoside, is a type of glycosphingolipid containing a tetrasaccharide core structure with the sequence GalNAcβ1-3Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glc, found in the P antigen (Gb4) glycosphingolipid.

A glycosphingolipid antigen with the structure GalNAcβ1-3Galα1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer, belonging to the globoseries. It is the defining determinant of the P blood group system, carried on glycolipids of red blood cells and other tissues. Along with related glycans such as Gb3 (Pk antigen), P antigen can act as a receptor for microbial toxins and lectins, and has been implicated in cancer cell recognition and signaling.
GD1a is a ganglioside, specifically a glycosphingolipid containing two sialic acid residues. It is commonly found in brain tissue and is a member of the GD1 ganglioside family.

src_content.definition: A branched amino hexasaccharide consisting of the linear sequence α-Neu5Ac-(2→3)-β-D-Gal-(1→3)-β-D-GalNAc-(1→4)-β-D-Gal-(1→4)-β-D-Glc having a Neu5Ac residue attached to a galactose via an α-(2→3) linkage. The oligosaccharide of ganglioside GD1a.[CHEBI:59209]
src_content.evidence: Exclusive exposure of rat oligodendrocytes to GD1a, but not other gangliosides, overcomes aggregated fibronectin-induced inhibition of myelin membrane formation, in vitro, and OPC differentiation in fibronectin aggregate containing cuprizone-induced demyelinated lesions in male mice. [PMID: 28899916]

src_content.description: GD1b is a ganglioside, specifically a glycosphingolipid containing two sialic acid residues. It is predominantly found in neural tissues and is a member of the GD1 ganglioside family.

src_content.definition: A branched amino hexasaccharide comprising a β-D-galactosyl-(1→4)-β-D-glucose disaccharide, the galactosyl residue of which carries β-D-galactosyl-(1→3)-N-acetyl-β-D-galactosaminyl and N-acetyl-α-neuraminyl-(2→8)-N-acetyl-α-neuraminyl disaccharide units through (2→4) and (2→3) linkages respectively. It is the carbohydrate portion of ganglioside GD1b.[CHEBI:59222]
src_content.evidence: Gangliosides have been known to play a role in the regulation of apoptosis in cancer cells. This study has employed disialyl-ganglioside GD1b to apoptosis in human breast cancer MCF-7 cells using exogenous treatment of the cells with GD1b and endogenous expression of GD1b in MCF-7 cells.[PMID: 27144558]

src_content.description: GD1 refers to a class of acidic glycosphingolipids known as gangliosides that contain two sialic acid residues. These molecules are commonly found in neural tissues, and the GD1 group includes specific members such as GD1a and GD1b.

src_content.evidence: Hormonal and metabolic disturbances observed in both adult and paediatric patients with Gaucher disease type 1 (GD1) are discussed in this review. The PubMed database was used to identify articles on endocrine and metabolic disorders in GD1.[PMID:31791361]

src_content.description: Gg4 (gangliotetraosylceramide) is a glycosphingolipid, specifically a ganglioside, consisting of a ceramide backbone attached to a tetrasaccharide chain. It belongs to the globo-series of glycolipids.

src_content.definition: An amino tetrasaccharide consisting of 2-acetamido-2-deoxy-β-D-galactopyranosyl, α-D-galactopyranosyl, β-D-galactopyranosyl, and β-D-glucopyranose units joined together in sequence by (1→3), (1→4), and (1→4) glycosidic linkages, respectively.[CHEBI:145578]
src_content.evidence: Here we report that PUGNAc treatment provokes globotetraosylceramide (Gb4Cer) accumulation in human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC).[PMID:28392398]

src_content.description: Glc3Man9GlcNAc2 is a fully assembled N-glycan precursor oligosaccharide consisting of three glucose, nine mannose, and two N-acetylglucosamine residues. It is transferred en bloc to nascent proteins, covalently linked to asparagine, during N-glycosylation in eukaryotes, representing the initial glycan attached to glycoproteins before further processing in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus.
A repeating disaccharide unit composed of glucuronic acid and N-acetylglucosamine, characteristic of the NAc-domains in glycosaminoglycans such as heparan sulfate.
A repeating disaccharide unit composed of glucuronic acid β1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine, which forms the backbone structure of chondroitin sulfate glycosaminoglycans.
A disaccharide epitope composed of glucuronic acid β1-3 linked to galactose, typically with a reducing end aglycone (R). It is recognized as the unsulfated HNK epitope.
A glycan motif in which N-acetylglucosamine phosphate is linked to mannose through a phosphodiester bond. This structure is recognized by the cation-independent mannose 6-phosphate receptor.
A disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-2 linked to mannose, which is α1-3 linked to another sugar. This structure is commonly found in branched N-glycan structures.
A disaccharide motif in which N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is β1-2 linked to mannose, which is α1-6 linked to another sugar. This structure is commonly found as part of branched N-glycan structures.
A disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-4 linked to galactose. This structure is commonly found in both N-glycans and O-glycans.
A disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-4 linked to another GlcNAc. This structure is a common core component in N-glycans.
A glycosphingolipid structure in which N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is β1-4 linked to glucose, and the glucose is attached to a ceramide moiety. This structure is found in certain invertebrates.

A core disaccharide structure found in complex-type N-glycans, consisting of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-4 linked to mannose (Man). This motif is produced by the enzyme MGAT3 and is recognized by the E-PHA lectin.
A repeating disaccharide unit of glucose (Glc) α1-4 linked to glucose, forming the linear backbone of glycogen and other α-glucans.

A glycosidic linkage in which glucose (Glc) is α1-linked to mannose (Man) through a phosphate group. This structure is associated with the activities of glucose phosphotransferase and Glc-1-phosphate phosphodiesterase.

A disaccharide modification found on O-fucosylated serine or threonine residues, where a glucose (Glc) is β1-3 linked to a fucose (Fuc) that is α-linked to serine or threonine. This structure is commonly present on thrombospondin type 1 repeats (TSRs).

Globo-series glycosphingolipids are a class of glycosphingolipids characterized by terminal α-galactose residues. They are the most abundant glycolipids in erythrocytes and are degraded by the enzyme α-galactosidase.

src_content.evidence: Results of TLC immunostaining of neutral glycolipids from the cDNA-transfected cells also supported the identity of the newly synthesized component as globoside. [PMID:10993897]

src_content.description: Glucans are polysaccharides composed of glucose monomers linked by glycosidic bonds. They include various linkage types (such as β1-3, β1-4, β1-6, α1-3, and α1-4) and form the structural basis of cellulose and other fungal and plant cell wall components.
A hemicellulosic polysaccharide composed of glucose and mannose residues, commonly found in fungal cell walls and plant tissues.
Glucosylceramide (Glc-Cer) is a glycosphingolipid composed of a ceramide backbone with a single glucose residue attached through a β-glycosidic linkage.

src_content.definition: Cerebrosides which contain as their polar head group a glucose moiety bound in glycosidic linkage to the hydroxyl group of ceramides. Their accumulation in tissue, due to a defect in beta-glucosidase, is the cause of Gaucher's disease.[MeSH:D005963]
src_content.evidence: Glucosylceramide (GlcCer), the initial GSL synthesized from ceramide by GCS (GlcCer synthase), is required for embryonic survival, but its role in the lung is unknown.[PMID:31265321]

function.content: The structural characterization of mixed membranes made of cationic lipids and glucosylceramides may be important for developing novel immunotherapeutic tools such as vaccine adjuvants.
Glucosylceramide (GlcCer), the initial GSL synthesized from ceramide by GCS (GlcCer synthase), is required for embryonic survival, but its role in the lung is unknown.

src_content.description: Glucuronoarabinoxylan is a hemicellulosic polysaccharide present in plant cell walls, particularly in grasses. It features a xylan backbone that is substituted with glucuronic acid and arabinose residues.

Glucuronoxylan is a hemicellulosic polysaccharide characterized by a xylan backbone substituted with α-D-glucuronic acid or methylated glucuronic acid at the O-2 position. It is a major component of secondary cell walls in woody and herbaceous eudicots as well as higher plants.

Glycogen is a highly branched glucose polymer composed mainly of α(1-4)-linked glucose residues with α(1-6)-linked branch points. It serves as a major glucose storage polysaccharide in animals, allowing for rapid mobilization of glucose when needed.

Glycoglycerolipids are a class of glycolipids characterized by glycan moieties attached to the C-3 hydroxyl group of diacylglycerol or alkyl(acyl)glycerol, distinguishing them from glycosphingolipids.

Glycoinositolphospholipids (GIPLs) are a class of glycolipids structurally related to glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, but are distinguished by extensive substitution with galactose, N-acetylglucosamine, and sialic acid residues.

Glycolipids are glycoconjugates composed of a glycan moiety attached to a lipid. They include major classes such as brain glycolipids, which are abundant in neural tissue, as well as shorter chain variants.

Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are linear polysaccharides composed of repeating acidic disaccharide units, typically containing a hexosamine and a hexose or hexuronic acid. These chains are often sulfated and are covalently attached to core proteins to form proteoglycans. GAGs, which include heparan sulfate, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, and others, are critical for protein interactions and the structure of the extracellular matrix in eukaryotes.

Glycosphingolipids (GSLs) are a subclass of glycolipids composed of a glycan (oligosaccharide) linked to a ceramide lipid moiety. They are major components of animal cell membranes, synthesized by the stepwise addition of sugars to ceramide, and are classified based on their glycan structures. GSLs play important roles in membrane structure, cell–cell recognition, and signal transduction. They are degraded in lysosomes, and defects in their catabolism can result in pathological accumulation.

Glycosylceramides are glycolipids consisting of a ceramide backbone linked to a short glycan chain, such as glucosylceramide (Glc-Cer) and galactosylceramide (Gal-Cer). These molecules are commonly found in fungi and play important roles in membrane structure and function.
A type of glycolipid composed of one or more monosaccharides attached to a diacylglycerol backbone, frequently featuring α1-6-linked galactopyranose residues.

Glycosylinositolphosphorylceramides (GIPCs) are plant- and fungi-specific glycolipids composed of a ceramide backbone linked to a glycosylated inositol phosphate headgroup. They are major components of the plant plasma membrane and are absent in animals.

GM1b is a ganglioside with the structure Neu5Acα2-3Galβ1-3GalNAcβ1-4Galβ1-4Glcβ1-1Cer. It is biosynthesized by the α2-3 sialylation of GA1. It participates in membrane organization and cell–cell recognition.

GM1 is a ganglioside, a type of glycosphingolipid containing one sialic acid residue. It consists of a ceramide lipid linked to a pentasaccharide glycan headgroup, which is recognized by proteins such as cholera toxin. GM1 is formed by the addition of galactose to GM2 and plays important roles as a receptor for cholera toxin and in cell signaling.

src_content.definition: A branched amino pentasaccharide consisting of the linear sequence β-D-Gal-(1→3)-β-D-GalNAc-(1→4)-β-D-Gal-(1→4)-β-D-Glc having a Neu5Ac residue attached to the inner galactose via an α-(2→3) linkage. The oligosaccharide of ganglioside GM1a.[CHEBI:59208]
src_content.evidence: GM1-induced fluidization of the phospholipid membranes and probable physical contact between bulky sugar head group of GM1 and spectrin, may explain the modulatory role of GM1 on aminophospholipid interactions with nonerythroid brain spectrin.[PMID: 29920238]

function.content: The branched pentasaccharide chain of ganglioside GM1 is a prominent cell surface ligand, for example, for cholera toxin or tumor growth-regulatory homodimeric galectins.

src_content.description: GM2 is a ganglioside, a type of glycosphingolipid containing one sialic acid residue, and is found in the brain. It serves as a biosynthetic precursor to GM1 and is characterized by a sialylated glycan structure. GM2 accumulates in certain lysosomal storage diseases such as Sandhoff disease, and its degradation requires the GM2-activator protein.

src_content.definition: A branched amino tetrasaccharide consisting of the linear sequence β-D-GalNAc-(1→4)-β-D-Gal-(1→4)-β-D-Glc having a Neu5Ac residue attached to the galactose via an α-(2→3) linkage. Corresponds to the carbohydrate portion of ganglioside GM2.[CHEBI:59220]
src_content.evidence: GM1 gangliosidosis has both central nervous system and systemic findings; while, GM2 gangliosidosis is restricted primarily to the central nervous system.[PMID: 27491214]

src_content.description: GM3, also known as Ganglioside GM3, is the simplest member of the ganglioside series. It consists of a ceramide linked to a sialylated lactose, containing a single sialic acid residue. GM3 serves as a precursor for more complex gangliosides and is involved in modulating insulin receptor responsiveness.

src_content.definition: Ganglioside GM3 (d18:1/16:0) is a glycosphingolipid (ceramide and oligosaccharide)or oligoglycosylceramide with one or more sialic acids (i.e. n-acetylneuraminic acid) linked on the sugar chain. It is a component the cell plasma membrane which modulates cell signal transduction events. Gangliosides have been found to be highly important in immunology. Ganglioside GM3 carries a net-negative charge at pH 7.0 and is acidic. Gangliosides can amount to 6% of the weight of lipids from brain, but they are found at low levels in all animal tissuesGangliosides are glycosphingolipids. There are four types of glycosphingolipids, the cerebrosides, sulfatides, globosides and gangliosides. Gangliosides are very similar to globosides except that they also contain N-acetyl neuraminic acid (NANA) in varying amounts. The specific names for the gangliosides provide information about their structure. The letter G refers to ganglioside, and the subscripts M, D, T and Q indicate that the molecule contains mono-, di-, tri and quatra-sialic acid. The numbered subscripts 1, 2 and 3 refer to the carbohydrate sequence that is attached to the ceramide. In particular, 1 stands for GalGalNAcGalGlc-ceramide, 2 stands for GalNAcGalGlc-ceramide and 3 stands for GalGlc-ceramide. Deficiencies in lysosomal enzymes that degrade the carbohydrate portions of various gangliosides are responsible for a number of lysosomal storage diseases such as Tay-Sachs disease, Sandhoff disease, and GM1 gangliosidosis. The carbohydrate portion of the ganglioside GM1 is the site of attachment of cholera toxin, the protein secreted by Vibrio cholerae.[HMDB0004844]
src_content.evidence: We also demonstrated an essential role of GM3 in murine and human auditory systems; a common pathological feature of GM3S deficiency is deafness. [PMID: 29747813]

function.content: Membrane stabilizer
Energy source
Energy storage
Molecular messenger:
Signaling molecule

src_content.description: GPI glycans are the glycan (oligosaccharide) portion of glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, which are glycolipid structures that tether proteins to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane. The core GPI glycan consists of a conserved sequence, typically including mannose and glucosamine residues linked to myo-inositol phospholipid, and serves as a scaffold for further modifications and protein attachment. GPI glycans can vary between species and tissues, contributing to the diversity of GPI-anchored proteins, and may include additional side chains. In some organisms, the lipid component is inositolphosphoceramide. The GPI glycan is preassembled before protein attachment and is essential for the function of GPI anchors.
GQ1b is a ganglioside, a type of glycosphingolipid that contains sialic acid. It is found in cell membranes and is recognized as an antigen in certain autoimmune responses.

src_content.definition: An amino oligosaccharide that is a branched octasaccharide derivative consisting of four sialyl residues, two galactose residues, one N-acetylglucosamine and a glucose residue at the reducing end.[CHEBI:59212]
src_content.evidence: Bilateral infusion of GQ1b into the hippocampus ameliorates cognitive deficits in the triple-transgenic AD mouse model (3xTg-AD).[PMID:31186474]

src_content.description: GT1b is a ganglioside, which is a type of glycosphingolipid containing sialic acid. It functions as a docking site for specific proteins and toxins on neuronal cells.

src_content.definition: A branched amino heptasaccharide comprising a β-D-galactosyl-(1→4)-β-D-glucose disaccharide, the galactosyl residue of which carries an N-acetyl-α-neuraminyl-(2→3)-β-D-galactosyl-(1→3)-N-acetyl-β-D-galactosaminyl trisaccharide unit and an N-acetyl-α-neuraminyl-(2→8)-N-acetyl-α-neuraminyl disaccharide unit through (2→4) and (2→3) linkages respectively. It corresponds to the carbohydrate portion of ganglioside GT1b.[CHEBI:59225]
src_content.evidence: GT1b ganglioside is axonally transported to the spinal cord dorsal horn and contributes to characteristics of neuropathic pain such as mechanical and thermal hypersensitivity.[PMID: 32030804]

src_content.description: GT1c is a ganglioside, a complex glycosphingolipid formed by the galactosylation of GT2 and characterized by the presence of multiple sialic acid residues.

src_content.definition: A branched amino heptasaccharide consisting of a linear tetrasaccharide of β-D-galactose, N-acetyl-β-D-galactosamine, β-D-galactose and β-D-glucose residues linked sequentially (1→3), (1→4) and (1→4), to the galactose residue proximal to the reducing end is also linked (2→3) an N-acetyl-α-neuraminyl-(2→8)-N-acetyl-α-neuraminyl-(2→8)-N-acetyl-α-neuraminyl trisaccharide side-chain. The carbohydrate moiety of ganglioside GT1c.[CHEBI:90509]
src_content.evidence: We show here that VVH associates with ganglioside GM1a, Fucosyl-GM1, GD1a, GT1c, and GD1b by glycan array.[PMID: 32228455]

src_content.description: Hemicellulose refers to a class of branched plant cell wall polysaccharides characterized by a backbone of 1-4-linked β-D-pyranosyl residues, such as glucose, mannose, or xylose. This group includes xylans, glucuronoxylans, galactomannans, and xyloglucans. Hemicelluloses are synthesized in the Golgi apparatus and secreted into the apoplast, where they contribute to the structure and function of plant cell walls.
The heparan sulfate backbone consists of a repeating disaccharide unit made up of glucuronic acid (GlcA) β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) α1-4.

Heparan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units of glucuronic acid (GlcA) and N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc), assembled as a copolymer and extensively modified by sulfation and epimerization. It is synthesized on a linkage tetrasaccharide attached to serine residues of core proteins, forming chains that are found on proteoglycans. Heparan sulfate oligosaccharides are short segments derived from or mimicking these chains. Heparan sulfate plays important roles in cell signaling and molecular interactions.

src_content.definition: A linear polysaccharide in which the backbone consists of a variably sulfated repeating disaccharide unit.[CHEBI:28815]
src_content.evidence: In Niemann-Pick C-1 fibroblasts, where deaminative degradation of heparan sulfate is defective, carbonylated proteins were abundant.[PMID: 17540770]

function.content: Heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGs) play crucial roles regulating key developmental signaling pathways, such as the Wnt, Hedgehog, transforming growth factor-beta, and fibroblast growth factor pathways.

src_content.description: Heparin is a highly sulfated glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units, typically containing N-sulfated glucosamine and iduronic acid, both variably sulfated. Structurally related to heparan sulfate, heparin chains are often attached to core proteins and are well known for their anticoagulant activity and high affinity for various proteins.

src_content.definition: A highly sulfated linear glycosaminoglycan comprising complex patterns of uronic acid-(1→4)-D-glucosamine repeating subunits. Used as an injectable anticoagulant, it has the highest negative charge density of any known biological molecule.[CHEBI:28304]
src_content.evidence: Two cellulose-based membranes, containing 5 and 20% N, N-diethyl-aminoethyl cellulose (DEAE) respectively, were investigated for ionic attachment of heparin and heparin release.[PMID:6416324]

src_content.description: Heteroxylan refers to a class of hemicellulosic polysaccharides found in the secondary cell walls of seed-producing plants. These polysaccharides are characterized by a β-1,4-linked D-xylopyranose backbone with various substituents, and are classified based on the type and abundance of these substituents.
A class of N-linked glycans characterized by multiple antennae (branches) that contain complex sugars. These highly branched structures are less likely to bind to ConA-agarose.

High-mannose N-glycans, also known as oligomannose-type glycans, are a class of N-linked glycans characterized by a core pentasaccharide (Man3GlcNAc2) that is extended exclusively with additional mannose residues, typically resulting in structures with five to nine mannose units. These glycans are biosynthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum from dolichol-linked precursors and are found on glycoproteins, where they play important roles in protein folding, quality control, trafficking, and recognition. High-mannose N-glycans can serve as ligands for lectins, are substrates for enzymes such as endo H, and may be further modified, for example by phosphorylation during lysosomal targeting. They lack complex antennae and are notable for their strong binding to ConA-agarose.

src_content.definition: An N-linked oligosaccharide that possesses between five and nine mannose residues attached to the chitobiose [(GlcNAc)2] core. [CHEBI:5717] None of the Man residues are substituted with any monosaccharide other than Man .
src_content.evidence: Each glycoform contained a number of peaks differing by 162 Da indicating heterogeneity and suggesting the presence of high-mannose sugars.[PMID:11258925]

function.content: Involved in promotion of protein folding in ER. [PMID:12417032].
High Man glycans are enriched at cell surface during apoptosis.

disease_association.content: Relative abundance changes in multiple CDGs [PMID: 30770376]

src_content.description: HNK-1 is a carbohydrate epitope, specifically 3-sulfoglucuronyl-galactose, found on various glycans, including those present on glycosphingolipids. Glycosphingolipids that display the HNK-1 epitope have this distinctive glycan structure on their glycan moiety.

src_content.definition: An amino trisaccharide consisting of a 3-O-sulfo-β-D-glucuronic acid residue, a D-galactosyl residue and an N-acetyl-D-glucosamine residue (at the reducing end) in a linear sequence.[CHEBI:60322]
src_content.evidence: The human natural killer-1 (HNK-1) carbohydrate, a unique trisaccharide possessing sulfated glucuronic acid in a non-reducing terminus (HSO3-3GlcAß1-3Galß1-4GlcNAc-), is highly expressed in the nervous system and its spatiotemporal expression is strictly regulated.[PMID:28709864]

function.content: learning and memory
neural crest cell migration
neurite extension
neuron-astrocyte adhesion

src_content.description: Homogalacturonan is a linear homopolysaccharide consisting of 1,4-linked α-D-galacturonic acid residues. It forms a major structural domain of pectin in plant cell walls, contributing to their integrity and function.

Hyaluronan is a high-molecular-weight, linear, nonsulfated glycosaminoglycan composed of repeating disaccharide units of glucuronic acid (GlcA) β1-3 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) β1-4. These long, polyanionic chains occupy large hydrodynamic volumes and play important roles in cell adhesion, signaling, and tissue structure. Short hyaluronan chains or oligosaccharides, generated by enzymatic cleavage, can interact with membrane proteins such as CD44 and TLR2/4, modulating signaling pathways and inducing biological effects including apoptosis in cancer cells.

src_content.evidence: Hyaluronan (HA) comprises a major component of the extracellular matrix (ECM) in vertebrate connective tissues and is abundant in the cartilage, skin, brain, vitreous body, umbilical cord, and synovial fluid. [PMID:33171800]

src_content.description: Hybrid N-glycans are a class of N-linked glycans that display features of both oligomannose and complex N-glycans. They are characterized by having one branch (antenna) that retains mannose residues, while the other branch is extended with N-acetylglucosamine and other complex sugars. These structures are biosynthesized when the GlcNAcMan5GlcNAc2 intermediate produced by MGAT1 is not fully processed by α-mannosidase II, resulting in glycans that are intermediates between oligomannose and complex N-glycans. Hybrid N-glycans can be further modified in the Golgi apparatus.

src_content.definition: An N-linked glycan in which the Manα1-6 arm of the trimannosyl core Manα1-3(Manα1-6)Manβ1-4GlcNAcβ1–4GlcNAcβ1–Asn-X-Ser/Thr is substituted by one or more additional Man residues and the Manα1-3 arm is substituted by a GlcNAc residue added by GlcNAcT1. The GlcNAc linked to the a3 Man can be extended in the same manner as any complex glycan antenna. The trimannosyl core can also be core fucosylated and/or bisected by the addition of a GlcNAc to the 3 position of the α-linked Man residue.[Essentials of Glycobiology:Chapter 9]
src_content.evidence: A hybrid-type N-glycan was accessed by total synthesis, converted to an oxazoline, and used as a donor substrate with both wild type Endo M and an N175Q glycosynthase Endo M mutant allowing the convergent synthesis of a glycosylated amino acid bearing a hybrid N-glycan structure. [PMID:27058295]

src_content.description: A branched poly-N-acetyllactosamine glycan determinant formed by β1-6 branching of repeating Galβ1-4GlcNAc units, distinguishing it from the linear i antigen. It is carried on N- and O-glycans and glycolipids, serves as part of the I blood group system, and its expression changes during development (i → I conversion) and in certain diseases.

src_content.definition: N-[(2R,3R,4R,5S,6R)-5-[(2S,3R,4S,5S,6R)-4-[(2R,3R,4R,5S,6R)-3-Acetamido-4-hydroxy-6-(hydroxymethyl)-5-[(2S,3R,4S,5R,6R)-3,4,5-trihydroxy-6-(hydroxymethyl)oxan-2-yl]oxyoxan-2-yl]oxy-6-[[(2R,3R,4R,5S,6R)-3-acetamido-4-hydroxy-6-(hydroxymethyl)-5-[(2S,3R,4S,5R,6R)-3,4,5-trihydroxy-6-(hydroxymethyl)oxan-2-yl]oxyoxan-2-yl]oxymethyl]-3,5-dihydroxyoxan-2-yl]oxy-2,4-dihydroxy-6-(hydroxymethyl)oxan-3-yl]acetamide (CHEBI:151390) is a amino sugar.[CHEBI:151390]
src_content.evidence: The I antigen is formed by the action of an enzyme (a glycosyltransferase), which adds branches onto the i antigen.[PMID:15679458]

src_content.description: The i antigen consists of repeating disaccharide units of N-acetyllactosamine (Galβ1-4GlcNAcβ1-3/6) arranged in a linear fashion. These linear poly-N-acetyllactosamine chains can act as precursors for further branching and are involved in the biosynthesis of antigens such as the I antigen.

src_content.evidence: Inasmuch as the hybridoma was established by hybridization of lymphocytes derived from regional lymph nodes of lung cancer, and the antigen was found in the patient's lung cancer tissue, the i antigen in lung cancer is probably recognized as a tumor-associated antigen by the host's immune cell system.[PMID:2422274]

src_content.description: Glycan antigens structurally related to keratan sulfate, including motifs such as the tetrasaccharide Galβ1-3GlcNAcβ1-3Galβ1-4GlcNAc, which are recognized by specific monoclonal antibodies such as TRA-1-60 and TRA-1-81.

Keratan sulfate (KS) is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) composed of repeating disaccharide units of galactose and N-acetylglucosamine, which are variably sulfated. These sulfated poly-N-acetyllactosamine chains are typically attached to core proteins at asparagine or serine/threonine residues, forming proteoglycans such as decorin, biglycan, versican, and lumican in various tissues.

src_content.definition: A sulfated glycosaminoglycan, a linear polymer that consists of the repeating disaccharide [3)-β-Gal-(1→4)-β-GlcNAc-(1→] and containing sulfo groups located at random positions.[CHEBI:60924]
src_content.evidence: Compared to the other classes of glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), that is, chondroitin/dermatan sulfate, heparin/heparan sulfate and hyaluronan, keratan sulfate (KS), have the least known of its interactive properties.[PMID: 30578672]

function.content: Tissue hydration.

src_content.description: LacdiNAc (N-acetylgalactosamine β1-4 N-acetylglucosamine, GalNAcβ1-4GlcNAc) is a disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc). It is commonly found as an outer structure in some invertebrate glycans and as a motif in N-glycans, with its presence determined by specific glycosyltransferases in lineage-specific glycosylation pathways. LacdiNAc is a glycan motif found in various taxa.

src_content.definition: An amino disaccharide consisting of N-acetylglucosamine having an N-acetylgalactosaminyl resiude attached at the 4-position via a β-linkage.[CHEBI:61190]
src_content.evidence: We previously showed that the expression level of the LacdiNAc group in N-glycans decreases dramatically during the progression of human breast cancer.[PMID:25003135]

function.content: Has a role of epitope.

src_content.description: LacNAc (N-acetyllactosamine, Galβ1-4GlcNAc) is a disaccharide motif commonly found in vertebrate N- and O-glycans, serving as a building block for more complex glycan structures such as Lewis antigens.

Lacto-series glycosphingolipids are a class of glycosphingolipids defined by a core structure containing N-acetyllactosamine (LacNAc) repeats. These glycolipids are especially prominent in secretory organs and play important roles in cellular recognition and membrane structure.

Lactosylceramide (LacCer) is a glycosphingolipid core structure composed of a galactose residue β1-4 linked to glucose, which is further attached to a ceramide moiety. It serves as the most common core structure of vertebrate glycosphingolipids.

src_content.definition: Glycosphingolipids which contain as their polar head group a lactose moiety bound in glycosidic linkage to the hydroxyl group of ceramide. Their accumulation in tissue, due to a defect in lactosylceramide beta-galactosidase, is the cause of lactosylceramidosis.[MeSH:D007790]
src_content.evidence: In the 1970s, a neutral glycosphingolipid lactosylceramide (LacCer) was found to bind specifically to several kinds of microorganisms.[PMID:30175814]

function.content: mammalian cell receptors for Neisseria gonorrhoeae recognized by Helicobacter pylori

src_content.description: A repeating disaccharide-phosphate unit composed of galactose (β1-4 linked to mannose) with a phosphate group, forming the backbone of the phosphoglycan polymer in Leishmania lipophosphoglycan (LPG) and related phosphoglycosylated protein glycans. This structural motif is characteristic of the phosphoglycan portions of LPG and proteophosphoglycan (PPG) in certain protozoa.
A fructan polysaccharide composed of linear β2-6-linked D-fructofuranose units, commonly found in grasses.

Lewis antigens are a family of fucosylated glycan epitopes, including Lewis a, b, x, and y, that function as blood group antigens and mediate cell-cell interactions. These structures are characterized by the addition of L-fucosyl residues to a glycan backbone, resulting in branched motifs commonly found on glycoproteins and glycolipids.
Lewis a is a fucosylated type 1 chain glycan epitope with the structure Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAc, commonly referred to as the Lewis a antigen.

src_content.definition: A lewis blood group antigen with structure beta-D-Galp-(1->3)-[alpha-L-Fucp-(1->4)]-D-GlcpNAc consisting of N-acetylglucosamine having a fucosyl residue attached at the 4-position via an alpha-linkage and a galactosyl residue attached at the 3-position via a beta-linkage. It has a role as an epitope and an antigen. It is an amino trisaccharide and a glucosamine oligosaccharide.[CHEBI:62265]
src_content.evidence: Regardless of the vaccine administered, significantly fewer of the children with Lewis A phenotype (0/14) seroconverted after receiving the first vaccine dose compared to 26% (45/175) of those with the Lewis B phenotype and 32% (15/47) of the Lewis negative individuals (P < 0.01). [PMID:29367698]

src_content.description: Lewis b is a fucosylated type 1 chain glycan epitope, with the structure Fucα1-2Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAc, and is known as the Lewis b antigen.

src_content.evidence: Human mannose-binding lectin preferentially binds to human colon adenocarcinoma cell lines expressing high amount of Lewis A and Lewis B antigens.[PMID:10328552]

function.content: possible receptor for Helicobacter pylori

src_content.description: Lewis x (Lex) is a fucosylated type 2 chain glycan epitope with the structure Galβ1-4(Fucα1-3)GlcNAc. It is found on N-glycans, O-glycans, and glycolipids in animals and some plants. Glycans containing the Lewis x motif are characterized by the addition of this fucosylated N-acetyllactosamine structure to the glycan chain.

src_content.definition: A Lewis blood group antigen with structure α-L-Fucp-(1→3)-[β-D-Galp-(1→4)]-D-GlcpNAc where the glucosamine at the reducing end has β-configuration at its anomeric centre. Commonly known as Lewis x trisaccharide or Lex.[CHEBI:59294]
src_content.evidence: In particular, the observation of oxonium ions at m/z 512.2 and 803.2 is useful for probing outer non-reducing terminal fucosylation, which represented carbohydrate structures consisting of Hex Hex , dHex Hex , and HexNAc , and NeuNAc , Hex Hex , dHex Hex , and HexNAc , respectively, from which the Lewis X structure (Galbeta1-4(Fucalpha1-3)GlcNAc) was readily deduced.[PMID:15536627]

function.content: Involved in carbohydrate-carbohydrate interaction[Glycoepitope:EP0011].
Also implicated in apoptosis.
influence antigenic presentation and interfere with pathogen transfer in breastfed infants.

src_content.description: The lipid A-core is a glycan-lipid structure in which lipid A is covalently linked to the core oligosaccharide region of lipopolysaccharide (LPS). This structure serves as a substrate for transport and further modification in Gram-negative bacteria.

Lipo-chitooligosaccharides (LCOs) are a class of glycolipids consisting of a chitin-derived oligosaccharide backbone linked to a fatty acid. They are produced by bacterial and fungal symbionts and are recognized by plant receptors, triggering various biological responses.

Lipoglycans are a broad class of glycoconjugates in which a glycan, such as an oligosaccharide or polysaccharide, is covalently linked to a lipid moiety. These molecules contribute to cell membrane structure and function.
A complex glycoconjugate composed of lipid, peptide, and phosphoglycan components, as exemplified by the lipopeptidophosphoglycan (LPPG) found in Entamoeba histolytica.

Lipophosphoglycan (LPPG) is a major surface glycoconjugate of Leishmania parasites, consisting of a phosphoglycan chain linked to a lipid anchor. It functions as a virulence factor and plays a key role in parasite biology.

Lipopolysaccharide is a major glycolipid component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, composed of lipid A, a core oligosaccharide, and an O-antigen polysaccharide. It acts as a potent antigen and pathogen-associated molecular pattern (PAMP).

Lipoteichoic acids (LTAs) are anionic glycopolymers present in the cell envelopes of Gram-positive bacteria. They typically consist of polyglycerol phosphate chains anchored to a glycolipid, and display diverse carbohydrate structures. Their biosynthetic pathways are distinct from those of wall teichoic acids.

M7BC is a specific isomer of the Man7 (M7) high-mannose N-glycan. It is characterized by the absence of residues i and k compared to M8B, resulting in the exposure of an α1–6-linked mannose (residue j). M7BC is generated from M8B through the enzymatic action of EDEM1 and EDEM3.
afucosylated high-mannose (7) N-glycan, non-mannosylated branch B and C
M8B is a specific isomer of the Man8 (M8) high-mannose N-glycan. It is generated from Man9 (M9) through demannosylation, a process mainly catalyzed by the enzyme EDEM2 in the endoplasmic reticulum.
afucosylated high-mannose (8) N-glycan, non-mannosylated branch B
A core N-glycan structure composed of three mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues, representing the minimal N-glycan core found in eukaryotes.
trimannosyl core of N-glycans
An N-glycan core structure consisting of five mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues, commonly found on glycoproteins and not associated with targeting them for degradation.
afucosylated high-mannose (5) N-glycan
An N-glycan core structure composed of six mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues, commonly found as an intermediate in the biosynthesis of N-linked glycans.
afucosylated high-mannose (6) N-glycan

N-glycans that contain mannose-6-phosphate (Man-6-P) residues. These glycans were first identified on lysosomal enzymes and are essential for proper lysosomal trafficking, serving as recognition markers for targeting enzymes to lysosomes.
Man7 (Man7GlcNAc2) is an N-glycan core structure composed of seven mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues. It represents a high-mannose intermediate in the biosynthesis of N-glycans.
afucosylated high-mannose (7) N-glycan
Man8 (Man8GlcNAc2) is an N-glycan core structure composed of eight mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues. It represents a high-mannose intermediate in the biosynthesis of N-glycans.
afucosylated high-mannose (8) N-glycan
Man9 (Man9GlcNAc2) is an N-glycan core structure composed of nine mannose and two N-acetylglucosamine residues. It represents a high-mannose intermediate in the biosynthesis of N-glycans.
afucosylated high-mannose (9) N-glycan

Mannans are polysaccharides composed mainly of mannose residues, typically linked by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds. They are found in plant cell walls, as well as in the cell walls of fungi, yeast, and some bacteria, where they can serve structural or signaling functions.

A type of N-linked glycan characterized by mannose residues at its non-reducing ends. These glycans play a role in targeting proteins to specific cells, such as macrophages, by serving as recognition signals.

Mannosylated lipoarabinomannan (ManLAM) is a form of lipoarabinomannan (LAM) found in mycobacteria, characterized by mannose residues capping its structure. As a glycolipid, ManLAM plays a key role in modulating immune responses by interacting with C-type lectin receptors.

This is a glycosylphosphoceramide structure identified in Aspergillus fumigatus, featuring a galactomannan chain with a defined mannosylated core (Manα1-2Manα1-2Manα1-6Manα1-4GlcN) that is directly linked to inositolphosphoceramide, notably lacking a bridging phosphoethanolamine.

A disaccharide consisting of two mannose residues connected by an α1-3 glycosidic bond. This structure can function as an inhibitor of mannose-binding proteins that are involved in adhesion processes.
A glycosphingolipid core structure found in certain invertebrates, consisting of a β1-4 linked mannose and glucose attached to a ceramide lipid.

Matriglycan is a specialized repeating disaccharide glycan synthesized on α-dystroglycan. It serves as a binding site for extracellular matrix proteins and certain viral proteins, and is an extended O-mannosyl glycan essential for the connection between muscle and the extracellular matrix.

Methanochondroitin is a rigid fibrillar polysaccharide similar to chondroitin, composed of repeating units of one uronic acid and two N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues, and is found as a cell surface polymer.

A monoantennary N-glycan is an N-glycan structure characterized by having a single antenna (branch) extending from the core. This type of glycan is often produced in engineered CHO cells, is typically unsialylated, and features exposed galactose acceptor sites.

A high-mannose-type N-glycan containing a single glucose residue. This structure is recognized by calnexin and calreticulin in the endoplasmic reticulum and plays a key role in the glycoprotein folding quality control system.

A ganglioside that contains a single sialic acid residue, such as GM3. These structures typically terminate in Neu5Acα2-3Gal and can be recognized by certain lectins, including those involved in HIV interactions.

Mucin-type O-glycans (O-GalNAc glycans) are a class of O-linked glycans that begin with the attachment of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to serine or threonine residues on proteins. They are commonly found on mucins and other glycoproteins, sharing a core GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr structure that can be further extended or modified by additional sugars.

Multiantennary complex-type N-glycans are N-glycans with a complex-type core structure that feature multiple antennae (branches) extending from the core mannose residues. These structures are characteristic of animal glycoproteins.

Neolacto-series glycosphingolipids are a class of glycosphingolipids (GSLs) defined by a neutral core sequence. They are commonly found on certain hematopoietic cells, including leukocytes, in mammals.

Neu5Acα2-3Gal is a disaccharide motif where N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac) is linked in an alpha 2-3 configuration to galactose (Gal). This structure is commonly found as a terminal motif on glycans and is recognized by certain viruses and lectins.

Neu5Acα2-6Gal is a disaccharide motif consisting of N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac) linked in an alpha 2-6 configuration to galactose (Gal). This structure is commonly found as a terminal motif on human airway epithelial cell glycans and serves as a receptor determinant for certain viruses.

This trisaccharide consists of N-glycolylneuraminic acid (Neu5Gc) linked α2-3 to galactose (Gal), which is β1-4 linked to glucose (Glc). It is found in certain glycolipids and is recognized by specific bacterial strains.

The N-glycan core is the conserved core structure (Manα1–6(Manα1–3)Manβ1–4GlcNAcβ1–4GlcNAcβ1–Asn) found in all N-linked glycans found on eukaryotic proteins. It is assembled during the process of N-glycosylation and is essential for the proper formation and function of glycoproteins.
A type of N-glycan that carries corneal-type keratan sulfate (KS, type I) chains and is degraded by enzymes involved in N-glycan catabolism.

N-glycans are a class of glycans covalently attached to the asparagine residues of proteins via N-glycosidic bonds. They are characterized by a conserved core pentasaccharide structure and are commonly found in animals, but the N-glycosylation system is present across all domains of life. N-glycans are synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi apparatus, and their structures can be further elaborated with various monosaccharides such as GlcNAc, GalNAc, Gal, Man, Fuc, and sialic acid. These glycans play important roles in protein folding, stability, and cell signaling.

src_content.definition: The carbohydrate portion of a glycoprotein that has a glycan linked through the nitrogen of an asparagine side-chain.[CHEBI:59520]
src_content.evidence: Our study identifies extracellular N-linked glycans-and the glycoprotein neurexin 1β specifically-as key modulators of neuronal uptake of αSacetyl, drawing attention to the potential therapeutic value of αSacetyl-glycan interactions.[PMID:31211781]

function.content: N-glycans modulate the function of several cell surface proteins which involved in migration, adhesion and which are responsible for regulating myelination.
Affect transportation of the glycosylated proteins in the Golgi.
Affects cell-cell interaction, adhesion, expression, proper folding.
extracellular N-glycans act as key modulators of neuronal uptake of αacetyl [PMID: 31211781].

src_content.description: Sialic acids that are modified by the addition of an O-acetyl group at one or more hydroxyl positions. These modifications can influence recognition by viral and immune receptors and are regulated by specific esterases.

The O-antigen is a repetitive glycan polymer that constitutes the outermost domain of the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in Gram-negative bacteria. It is highly variable in structure and serves as a major determinant of antigenic diversity among bacterial strains.
