O-fucose glycans are glycans in which fucose is O-linked to serine or threonine residues, most notably found on Notch receptors. These structures play important roles in regulating signaling pathways that are critical for cell differentiation and development.

src_content.definition: Form of glycosylation where the protein is modified by a fucose residue and can be extended futher to form a tetrasaccharide in certain cases. alpha-linked o-fucose have a consensus motif of C2X4(s/T)C3 where C2 and C3 are conserved cysteines number 2 and 3 respectively of the EGFR like repeats. [Essentials of Glycobiology:Chapter13]
src_content.evidence: Recently, a number of laboratories have shown that O-fucose glycans on the epidermal growth factor (EGF)-like repeats of the Notch extracellular domain modulate Notch signaling.[PMID:12417415]

function.content: modification of Notch signaling.

src_content.description: O-GalNAc core structures are conserved oligosaccharide cores formed by the extension of the initial O-linked GalNAc residue on serine or threonine. These structures, known as cores 1–4, serve as the foundational building blocks for complex O-GalNAc glycans, particularly in mucins, and are essential for O-glycan biosynthesis in vertebrates.

O-GalNAc glycans are a class of O-linked glycans initiated by the attachment of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) to serine or threonine residues on proteins. They are commonly found in mucins and other glycoproteins, and can be extended to form diverse structures, including blood group and Lewis antigens.

O-GalNAc-linked sialoglycans are a type of O-GalNAc glycan that have been further modified by the addition of sialic acid residues. These structures are commonly found on mucins and other glycoproteins, where the sialic acid imparts extended and negatively charged properties to the glycan chains.

O-Glc glycans are glycans composed of a single glucose residue that is O-linked to serine or threonine residues of proteins. This type of O-glycosylation is found in various glycoconjugates and represents a simple form of protein glycosylation.

O-glycans are a class of glycans covalently attached to the serine or threonine residues of proteins via O-glycosidic bonds. Common in animals, they display diverse core structures often containing GalNAc, GlcNAc, Gal, fucose, and sialic acid. O-glycans are synthesized in the Golgi apparatus and play important roles in protein function, stability, and cell-cell interactions.

src_content.definition: The carbohydrate portion of a glycoprotein that has a glycan linked through the hydroxyl oxygen of serine, threonine, hydroxylysine or hydroxyproline side-chains.[CHEBI:59521]
src_content.evidence: Among these, six fucosylated N-linked glycansand four O-linked glycans exhibited significantly increased expression levels in GC, while five fucosylated N-linked glycans and ten fucosylated O-linked glycans exhibited significantly decreased expression levels in GC.[PMID:29865036]

function.content: Affects several important activities like protein stability, modulation of signaling molecules and enzyme activity.

src_content.description: Oligogalacturonides are oligosaccharides consisting of linear chains of galacturonic acid residues, usually generated by the partial degradation of pectin. They play important roles in plant growth, development, and defense signaling.

Oligoglucosides are oligosaccharides composed of glucose residues, often featuring 1-6 or 1-3 β-glucose linkages. They can be released from cell walls and may function as signaling molecules, such as oligosaccharins, in plant-pathogen interactions.

Oligomannose refers to glycan structures containing multiple mannose residues, commonly found as part of N-glycans or other glycan classes. These structures are recognized by specific lectins and are involved in protein interactions.

O-linked fucose refers to a glycan modification in which a fucose residue is attached via an O-linkage to serine or threonine residues of proteins. This modification is particularly important in modulating developmental signaling pathways, such as those involving the Notch receptor.
A disaccharide composed of glucose and galactose that is O-linked to hydroxylysine residues, playing an important role in collagen fibril formation.
Glucose residues attached via O-linkage to serine or threonine residues of proteins, which can be further extended by xylose in certain organisms.
Keratan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan that can be O-linked to proteins, especially in skeletal tissues (type II).

A glycan modification in which a mannose residue is attached via an O-linkage to serine or threonine residues of proteins. This modification is conserved across species and is implicated in muscular dystrophies.

O-GlcNAc refers to a single N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) residue attached via an O-linkage, typically a β-linkage, to serine or threonine residues of nuclear, cytoplasmic, and mitochondrial proteins. This modification is a dynamic post-translational modification found in multicellular eukaryotes.

src_content.definition: Form of glycosylation which exclusively occurs in the mitochondrial, cytoplasmic or nuclear compartments of the cell where the protein is modified by a GlcNAc monosaccharide on the serine or threonine residues and is generally not modified or elongated further to form more complex structures. [Essentials of Glycobiology:Chapter19]
src_content.evidence: A better understanding of the mechanisms of OGT/OGA action would enable us to derive therapeutic benefits of resetting cellular O-GlcNAc levels within an optimal range.[PMID:30464755]

src_content.description: O-glycans that are terminated or modified with sialic acid residues, which can be recognized by carbohydrate recognition domains in certain proteins and play roles in cell attachment.

O-mannose glycans are a class of O-glycans initiated by the attachment of mannose to serine or threonine residues of proteins. Found in mammals, yeast, and other organisms, these glycans can be extended into several core structures, such as core M1 and M2. They play important roles in protein function, cell signaling, and act as receptors for viruses and extracellular matrix proteins. In mammals, O-mannose glycans are especially abundant in the brain and on α-dystroglycan, with defects in their biosynthesis linked to congenital muscular dystrophies.

src_content.definition: O-linked glycans that are initiated by the addtion of a Man residue to Ser or Thr. Subsequent extension of the Man defines the O-Man core type, either M1, M2, or M3. The M1 type is initated by addition of a GlcNAc in β-linkage to the 2 position of the Man residue. M2 is initiated by addition of another GlcNAc to the 6 position of the M1 core. M3 is initiated by the addition of a GlcNAc in β-linkage to the 4 position of the Man residue. M1 and M2 type core glycans can be extended and branched with Gal, Fuc, Sialic Acid, and GlcA. The M3 core is uniquely extended by a multienzyme system to generate the matriglycan polysaccharide, a protein-specific modification found only on alpha-dystroglycan. [CHEBI:87761]
src_content.evidence: Protein O-linked mannose beta-1,4-N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase 2 (POMGNT2) catalyzes the first step toward the functional matriglycan structure on alpha-dystroglycan that is responsible for binding extracellular matrix proteins and certain arenaviruses.[PMID: 27932460]

disease_association.content: Muscle-Eye-Brain disease (MEB) and Walker-Warburg Syndrome (WWS) have mutations in genes encoding glycosyltransferases needed for O -mannosyl oligosaccharide synthesis
Muscular dystrophy and neuronal migration disorder are caused by mutations in a glycosyltransferase, POMGnT1.

src_content.description: A disaccharide motif in which fucose is α1-3 linked to N-acetylglucosamine. This structure is commonly found on the outer branches of N-glycan chains and plays a role in glycan degradation pathways.

A glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chain that is covalently attached to a core protein through an O-linked xylose residue. This structure includes dermatan sulfate (DS), chondroitin sulfate (CS), and heparan sulfate (HS), all of which share a common core tetrasaccharide linkage region.
The P1 antigen is a specific glycan structure expressed on the urothelium, where it facilitates bacterial attachment and infection.

src_content.definition: An amino pentasaccharide consisting of α-D-galactose, β-D-galactose N-acetyl-α-D-glucosamine, β-D-galactose, and β-D-glucose residues joined in sequence with ((1→4)-, (1→4)-, (1→3)- and (1→4)-linkages, respectively.[CHEBI:68484]
src_content.evidence: The P1 antigen was disovered in 1927 by Landsteiner and Levine, and Pk and NOR were described in 1951 and 1982, respectively.[PMID: 24046920]

src_content.description: Paucimannose N-glycans are a class of truncated N-linked glycans characterized by a chitobiose core (GlcNAc2) and a reduced number of mannose residues, typically two or three, but sometimes up to five (e.g., Man2–5GlcNAc2). These structures often lack sialic acids and other anionic groups, and may be modified by core α1-6-fucosylation or other substitutions. Paucimannose N-glycans arise from extensive trimming of high-mannose N-glycans during glycan processing, involving the action of Golgi β-hexosaminidases and α-mannosidase, resulting in shorter glycan chains compared to complex or oligomannose N-glycans. They are commonly found in insects, plants, some invertebrates, and occasionally in mammals.

src_content.definition: Any N-linked glycan derivative with composition Man1-4Fuc0-1 GlcNAc2, in which the chitobiose core (GlcNAc2) is intact. Found in relatively large amounts in invertebrates and plants, they are formed by removal of the non-reducing terminal GlcNAc (\added by GlcNAcT1) from GlcNAcMan3-5GlcNAc2 by a Golgi hexosaminidase and subsequent removal of Man residues by Golgi mannosidases. Pauscimannose glycans have also been detected in vertebrates.[CHEBI:144386]
src_content.evidence: The galactosylation of core fucose (GalFuc epitope) in paucimannose and complex-type N-glycans is characteristic of protostome organisms, including flatworms (planarians).[PMID:29475940]

src_content.description: P blood group antigens are glycan structures, specifically glycosphingolipids, present on red blood cells. They serve as targets for specific antibodies, influencing blood group compatibility, and also act as receptors for certain bacterial adhesins, playing a role in susceptibility to urinary tract infections.

Pectin is a structurally complex class of plant cell wall polysaccharides that are rich in 1-4-linked α-D-galacturonic acid (GalpA). It is primarily found in the primary cell walls of dicots, gymnosperms, and nongraminaceous monocots.
Phosphomannan refers to polysaccharides composed of mannose residues with phosphate groups, commonly found in fungal cell walls.
Phosphopeptidomannan refers to immunogenic mannans that contain both phosphate and peptide groups, typically found in yeast cell walls.
Glycan motifs characterized by multiple fucose residues attached as branches, frequently observed in schistosome glycoconjugates and associated with antigenic determinants like Lewisx and LacdiNAc.

Polyglycosylceramides are a class of glycolipids, also known as macroglycolipids, characterized by long glycan chains—often containing poly-N-acetyllactosamine—attached to a ceramide lipid anchor. These molecules can carry blood group antigens such as A, B, and H.
A glycan motif composed of repeating lacto-N-biose units (Galβ1-3GlcNAcβ1-3)n, commonly found as side chains on certain glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors, especially in protozoan parasites.
A polymannose has a backbone composed of repeating α1-6 linked mannose residues, characteristic of yeast N-glycans and forming the core of large polymannosyl structures.
A class of N-glycans found in yeast, characterized by large polymannosyl chains built on a poly(Manα1-6)n backbone.

Poly-N-acetylglucosamine is a bacterial exopolysaccharide composed of β1-6 linked N-acetylglucosamine residues. It is widely distributed among both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria and plays a significant role in biofilm formation and immune evasion.

Poly-N-acetyllactosamine (poly-LN) refers to a linear or branched glycan motif composed of repeating disaccharide units of galactose β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine β1-3, denoted as (Galβ1-4GlcNAcβ1-3)n. These chains are commonly found on N- and O-glycans as well as glycolipids, where they can be further modified with sialic acid and fucose. Poly-N-acetyllactosamine structures serve as scaffolds for terminal glycan modifications and are recognized by galectins.

Polysaccharide A (PSA) is a capsular polysaccharide characterized by zwitterionic properties. It is notable for its immunomodulatory role and its involvement in the maturation of the immune system. Polysaccharide A is distinct from polysialic acids.

Polysialic acid (polySia) is a linear homopolymer of sialic acid (N-acetylneuraminic acid, Neu5Ac) residues, typically linked via α2-8 or α2-9 glycosidic bonds. These chains are commonly found on glycoproteins such as neural cell adhesion molecules (NCAM) and play important roles in vertebrate brain development, neural cell migration, and immune modulation.

src_content.evidence: Polysialic acid (PSA) is a carbohydrate composed of a linear polymer of α2,8-linked sialic acids, primarily attached to the Neural Cell Adhesion Molecule (NCAM). [PMID:36076963]

src_content.description: Pseudomurein is a glycan-based polymer present in the cell walls of certain methanogenic Archaea. It consists of glycan strands cross-linked by peptides composed of L-amino acids, and is structurally distinct from the peptidoglycan found in bacterial cell walls.
Raffinose is part of a class of plant oligosaccharides, including stachyose and verbascose, which are water-soluble carbohydrates commonly found throughout the plant kingdom.
Rhamnogalacturonan II (RG-II) is a complex pectic polysaccharide domain present in plant cell walls, typically existing as a dimer cross-linked by a borate ester.

Rhamnogalacturonan I (RG-I) is a pectic polysaccharide characterized by a backbone of repeating disaccharide units composed of 4-α-D-galacturonic acid (GalpA) and 2-α-L-rhamnose (Rhap). It is a structural domain of pectin and can contain various side chains, such as arabinogalactan.

Rhamnogalacturonan is a class of pectic polysaccharides found in plant cell walls, characterized by a backbone composed of rhamnose and galacturonic acid residues, and often featuring diverse oligosaccharide side chains.
Rhamnomannan is a complex polysaccharide found in fungal cell walls, composed of rhamnose and mannose residues.
A glycopeptide motif in which N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is α-linked to the amino acid arginine. This structure is found in certain bacterial virulence factors.

The Sda antigen is a glycan motif defined by the terminal structure GalNAcβ1-4(Neu5Acα2-3)Galβ1-, which is recognized by specific monoclonal antibodies and found on certain glycoproteins and glycolipids.

src_content.definition: A branched amino tetrasaccharide comprised of a trisaccharide chain of N-acetyl-α-neuraminic acid, β-D-galactose and N-acetyl-β-D-glucosamine residues linked sequentially (2→3) and (1→4), to the galactose residue of which is also linked (1→4) an N-acetyl-β-L-galactosamine residue. [CHEBI:71561]
src_content.evidence: The expanding roles of the Sd(a)/Cad carbohydrate antigen and its cognate glycosyltransferase B4GALNT2.[PMID:24112972]

src_content.description: Glycolipids that are modified with both sialic acid and fucose residues, which are implicated in leukocyte adhesion and inflammatory responses.
Polymers composed of repeating sialoglycan units, which can interact with Siglec receptors and modulate immune cell functions such as apoptosis.

Sialoglycans are glycans (oligosaccharides or polysaccharides) that contain one or more sialic acid residues, typically as terminal (outermost) sugars on structures such as N-glycans, O-glycans, glycosphingolipids, milk oligosaccharides, or glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI) anchors. These molecules play important roles in cell recognition, immune modulation, and interactions with pathogens.

Sialoglycolipids are glycolipids that contain one or more sialic acid residues. Examples include gangliosides, which are abundant in neural tissues and play important roles in cell recognition and signaling.

A type of N-linked glycan characterized by a core structure with two antennae (biantennary), each ending with sialic acid residues. These glycans are commonly found on human glycoproteins, including therapeutic proteins such as erythropoietin.

src_content.definition: A binantennary glycan with one or two sialic acid residues as non-reducing terminal residues on one or both antennae. [RN]
src_content.evidence: Simbucus nigra agglutinin or an antibody specific to sialylated lactosamine with a preference for Neu5Acalpha2-6Gal rather than Neu5Acalpha2-3Gal reduced sperm binding to oviduct isthmic cells, as did occupying putative receptors on sperm with sialylated biantennary glycans.[PMID:23115267]

src_content.description: Glycolipids that contain sialic acid residues, which are recognized by myelin-associated glycoprotein and play a role in the inhibition of neuronal sprouting.

Sialylated glycosphingolipids are glycosphingolipids that contain sialic acid residues. They are widely distributed in animal families, with the exception of arthropods, and are also referred to as gangliosides.

Sialylated N-acetyllactosamine refers to N-acetyllactosamine disaccharides that have a terminal sialic acid residue. These structures are found in bacterial capsules and serve as targets for certain antibodies.

Sialylated N-glycans are N-linked glycans that possess terminal sialic acid residues. These structures are commonly found on glycoproteins, such as the IgG Fc domain, and play important roles in modulating antibody effector functions and other biological processes.

O-linked glycans that are initiated by N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) and further modified by the addition of sialic acid residues, typically through the action of α2-3 sialyltransferases such as ST3GAL1.
Sialylated O-glycans are O-linked glycans that possess terminal sialic acid residues. These structures can be biosynthesized in engineered yeast expressing human sialyltransferases.

Sialyl Lewis a (sLea) is a tetrasaccharide glycan motif with the structure Neu5Acα2-3Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAc. It serves as a binding determinant for E-selectin and is recognized as a biomarker in cancer diagnostics, notably detected by the CA19-9 assay.

src_content.definition: A sialyated version of Lewis A with a branched structure of amino tetrasaccharide consisting of a sialyl residue, linked (2→3) to a galactosyl residue that in turn is linked (1→3) to a glucosaminyl residue at the reducing end, which is also carrying a fucosyl residue at the 4-position.[CHEBI:62681]
src_content.evidence: By comparing the serum O-glycan profiles from healthy controls with those of cancer patients, we identified a marker candidate, core 1 sialyl Lewis A (NeuAcα2-3Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAcβ1-3Gal) (abbreviated C1SLA), whose concentration appeared to be weakly correlated with CA19-9 values.[PMID:26641888]

function.content: The carbohydrate determinants,Sialyl Lea and Sialyl Lex,which are frequently expressed on human cancer cells,serve as ligands for a cell adhesion molecule of the selectin family,E-selectin,which is expressed on vascular endothelial cells. These carbohydrate determinants are involved in the adhesion of cancer cells to vascular endothelium and thus contribute to hematogenous metastasis of cancer.

src_content.description: A tumor-associated carbohydrate antigen identical to the sialyl Lewis a (sLeᵃ) tetrasaccharide [Neu5Acα2-3Galβ1-3(Fucα1-4)GlcNAc]. It functions as an E-selectin ligand and serves as the principal serum biomarker for pancreatic and gastrointestinal adenocarcinomas, where it is widely used for diagnostic and prognostic purposes.

Sialyl Lewis x (sLex) is a tetrasaccharide glycan motif with the structure Neu5Acα2-3Galβ1-4(Fucα1-3)GlcNAc. It is a well-known selectin ligand involved in cell adhesion, particularly mediating leukocyte rolling, trafficking, and extravasation during inflammation and immune responses. sLex can be found as a terminal cap on both N- and O-glycans, including core 2 O-glycans, and is used as a biomarker in various biological and pathological processes such as hematopoiesis and leukemogenesis.

src_content.definition: A sialylated version of Lewis X antigen expressed on cell surfaces with structure alpha-Neup5Ac-(2->3)-beta-D-Galp-(1->4)-[alpha-L-Fucp-(1->3)]-beta-D-GlcpNAcis α-Neup5Ac-(2→3)-β-D-Galp-(1→4)-[α-L-Fucp-(1→3)]-D-GlcpNAc in which the anomeric configuration of the reducing-end N-acetyl-beta-D-glucosamine residue is beta. It is a ligand for selectins. [MESH:2030970,CHEI:71622]
src_content.evidence: As sialyl Lewis X is a lignad of the selectin family, it has been proposed that sialyl Lewis X-rich colon cancer cells metastasize to the liver by adhesion to selectins on hepatic endothelial cells.[PMID:12828079]

function.content: Sialyl Lex was shown to be a specific ligand on human leukocytes for vascular E- and P-selectins,and was shown to mediate leukocyte recruitment.
The determinant is also frequently expressed on human cancer cells,and is involved in the adhesion of cancer cells to vascular endothelium and thus contribute to hematogenous metastasis of cancer.

src_content.description: Sialyl-Tn is a truncated O-glycan structure (Neu5Acα2-6GalNAcα-) formed by the sialylation of the Tn antigen. It is commonly overexpressed in various cancers and serves as a notable cancer-associated glycan epitope.

The Sialyl-Tn antigen is a glycan structure composed of N-acetylneuraminic acid (Neu5Ac) linked in an α2-6 configuration to N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) in α configuration. It is recognized as a tumor-associated carbohydrate antigen.

src_content.definition: N-acetyl-alpha-neuraminyl-(2→6)-N-acetyl-alpha-D-galactosamine is an N-acetyl-alpha-neuraminyl-(2→6)-N-acetyl-D-galactosamine in which the carbon bearing the anomeric hydroxy group has alpha configuration. It has a role as an epitope. It derives from a N-acetyl-alpha-D-galactosamine and a N-acetyl-alpha-neuraminic acid.[CHEBI:61818]
src_content.evidence: The interaction between Siglec-15 and tumor-associated sialyl-Tn antigen enhances TGF-β secretion from monocytes/macrophages through the DAP12-Syk pathway.[PMID:23035012]

function.content: apoptosis of monocyte-derived dendritic cells
decrease of adhesion and increase of migration
increase of tumor growth
associated with morphological changes, decreased growth and increased migration of MDA-MB-231 cells.

src_content.description: A trisaccharide glycan structure where sialic acid (Sia) is α2-3 linked to galactose (Gal), which is β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc). This structure can be formed by elongation of O-GlcNAc with β1,4Gal followed by sialylation.

A trisaccharide glycan structure consisting of sialic acid (Sia) α2-6 linked to galactose (Gal), which is β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc). This motif is recognized by CD22 on B lymphocytes.

A glucose residue attached through a sulfur atom (S-glycosidic bond) rather than the usual oxygen linkage. This type of linkage is found in compounds such as glucosinolates and can be released by the action of myrosinase.
SSEA-4 is a glycosphingolipid (ganglioside) known as stage-specific embryonic antigen-4, which serves as a marker for embryonic stem cells and cancer stem cells.

src_content.evidence: Glycosphingolipids (GSLs), such as the globo-series GSLs stage-specific embryonic antigen 3 (SSEA-3), SSEA-4, and Globo-H, are specifically expressed on pluripotent stem cells and cancer cells, and are known to be associated with various biological processes such as cell recognition, cell adhesion, and signal transduction.[PMID:31817926]

src_content.description: Starch is a storage polysaccharide in plants composed of glucose units, typically arranged in insoluble, semicrystalline granules found within chloroplasts or amyloplasts.
A class of sulfated polysaccharides composed mainly of galactose residues, such as agarose and carrageenan, commonly found in red seaweeds.
Glycans that contain sulfated glucuronic acid residues, such as those found in the HNK-1 epitope, which is recognized by specific monoclonal antibodies.

Sulfated glycans are glycans that contain sulfate groups. This category includes a variety of structures, such as those recognized by L-selectin, the HNK-1 epitope, and pituitary glycoprotein hormones.

Sulfated glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) are a class of linear polysaccharides that include heparan sulfate, chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, and keratan sulfate. These molecules are characterized by the presence of sulfate groups and are typically covalently attached to core proteins in proteoglycans. They play important roles in cell signaling, extracellular matrix structure, and protein interactions.
N-glycans that are modified by the addition of sulfate groups, as seen in structures present on pituitary gonadotropin hormones and in keratan sulfate.
O-glycans of the mucin type that are modified by sulfation, and have been detected in species such as Drosophila and mosquito.

Terminal N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues that are β-linked and sulfated. These motifs are found on pituitary glycoprotein hormones such as lutropin (LH) and thyrotropin (TSH), where they play a role in the structure and function of these glycoproteins.
A glycosphingolipid composed of a galactosylceramide (GalCer) molecule with a sulfate group attached, commonly found in myelin and various other tissues.

src_content.evidence: In a previous study we found that sulfatide was efficient in lowering HIV-1 viral loads in SCID mice engrafted with human fetal liver/thymus tissues (SCID-hu).[PMID:23550344]

src_content.description: The T antigen is a disaccharide glycan structure consisting of galactose (Gal) β1-3 linked to N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) O-linked to serine or threonine, representing the core 1 structure of mucin-type O-glycans. It is commonly found as a core 1 O-glycan on glycoproteins, recognized by certain lectins, and is associated with tumor cells.

src_content.definition: An amino disaccharide composed of D-galactose and N-acetyl-α-D-galactosaminyl residues in β-(1→3) linkage.[CHEBI:61820]
src_content.evidence: Tn, sTn, and T antigen neo- or over-expression occurs in many types of cancer including gastric, colon, breast, lung, esophageal, prostate, and endometrial cancer.[PMID:27679419]

function.content: accumulation Lipoprotein(a) or LDL within arterial walls in atherogenesis
cancer progression (increase interaction/communication of the cells)
T antigen expression in RMA lymphoma cells leads to a reduced growth of the tumor
correlation with elevated Golgi pH in cancer cell (breast, colorectal cancer cells)
T antigen on apical surfaces of corneal epithelial cells provide protection against rose bengal penetrance.
reduction of a flexibility of the glycosidic bond and thereby favour certain glycan conformation
T antigen is a target for NK cell-mediated lysis
inverse relationship between T antigen expression and VWF plasma levels

disease_association.content: invasive pneumococcal infection (hemolytic uremic syndrome, hemolytic anemia)

src_content.description: Teichoic acids are polymers composed of repeating glycerol or ribitol phosphate units joined by phosphodiester linkages, and are found in the cell wall of Gram-positive bacteria.
A glycan structure featuring a fucose residue at the non-reducing terminus of glycan chains, as found in H and Lewis antigens. These terminal fucose residues can be cleaved by fucosidases.
A galactose residue located at the non-reducing end of a glycan, often exposed after the removal of terminal sialic acids. This structural feature can influence glycan recognition and function.
Glucuronic acid residues present at the non-reducing end of glycan chains, commonly observed in certain N-glycans.
Mannose residues located at the non-reducing end of glycan chains, which are important for recognition by mannose receptors.
N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues located at the non-reducing end of glycan chains, commonly present on certain N-glycans and recognized by specific lectins and receptors.

A glycan feature where N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) is present at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. This terminal GlcNAc can serve as an acceptor for galactosyltransferases and is recognized by certain lectins, playing a role in glycan recognition and modification.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of sialic acid (Sia) residues at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. These terminal sialic acids can be removed by mild acid treatment or further modified, and their removal exposes the underlying sugar residues.

A glycan feature where a mannose residue is present at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain, linked via an α1-6 glycosidic bond. This terminal α1-6 mannose is important for recognition by specific endoplasmic reticulum lectins and plays a role in ER-associated degradation pathways.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of an α-linked fucose residue at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. This structural motif is recognized by certain lectins and adhesion molecules, playing important roles in molecular recognition and cell signaling.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of α-linked galactose at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. The occurrence or absence of terminal α-galactose can be used to distinguish glycan types among different species or cell lines.
A glycan feature where α-linked mannose is present at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain; this motif is recognized by certain lectins and adhesion molecules.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of β-linked galactose at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain. This terminal structure can serve as a substrate for sialylation or be recognized by specific lectins.

A glycan feature characterized by the presence of N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) at the nonreducing end of a glycan chain in a β-linkage. This terminal structure is recognized by specific lectins and receptors, including the asialoglycoprotein receptor and the AMR.

A tetraantennary N-glycan is an N-linked glycan structure characterized by four antennae (branches) extending from the core. These branches often terminate in β-linked galactose (Gal) or N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues and are frequently associated with increased sialylation. Tetra-antennary N-glycans are notable for their enhanced biological activity, such as in erythropoietin (EPO), and can exhibit high-affinity binding to certain receptors, including the rat AMR.

src_content.definition: Type of N-linked glycan in which four antennae are present on the trimannosyl core, each initiated by GlcNAc additions catalyzed by position-specific N-acetylglucosaminyltransferases (GlcNAcTs). The four antennae are initiated by addition of 2 GlcNAcs to the _3 Man (at the 2 and 4 positions) and 2 GlcNAcs to the _6 Man (at the 2 and 6 positions) of the trimannosyl core. Each antenna can be extended or capped with HexNAc, deoxyHex, Hex, or sialic acid residues.  [Essentials of Glycobiology:Glossary]
src_content.evidence: In contrast, myeloma IgE showed a higher abundance of triantennary and tetraantennary glycan structures and a low abundance of species with a bisecting N-acetylglucosamine.[PMID:24308486]

src_content.description: The Tn antigen is a single N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residue O-linked to serine or threonine on proteins. It represents the simplest O-GalNAc glycan structure and is the initial product of mucin-type O-glycosylation.

src_content.definition: Tn anitigen or alpha-galnac or N-Acetylgalactosamine is an N-acetyl-D-galactosamine having alpha-configuration at the anomeric centre. It has a role as an epitope. It derives from an alpha-D-galactosamine.[CHEBI:40356,HMDB0000212]
src_content.evidence: Furthermore, we confirmed that LS174T cells (Tn-positive) transfected with wild-type Cosmc, thus expressing no Tn antigen, had down-regulation of H-Ras expression and subsequent inhibition of EMT process.[PMID:30637914]

function.content: lymphatic metastasis
tube formation in Drosophila development
modulation of malignant phenotype (gastric carcinoma cell)
correlation with tumor stage, lymphatic invasion and lymph node matastasis

src_content.description: A glycolipid composed of a trehalose disaccharide esterified at both 6-positions with mycolic acids. It serves as a key virulence factor in Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Mycobacterium bovis.

A triantennary N-glycan is an N-linked glycan structure featuring three antennae (branches) extending from the core. These branches often terminate in β-linked galactose (Gal) or N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residues. Triantennary N-glycans are recognized for their high-affinity binding to the rat asialoglycoprotein receptor (AMR).

src_content.definition: Type of N-linked glycan in which three antennae are present on the trimannosyl core, each initiated by GlcNAc additions catalyzed by position-specific N-acetylglucosaminyltransferases (GlcNAcTs). The three antennae can be be initiated by addition of 2 GlcNAcs to the _3 Man (at the 2 and 4 positions) and 1 GlcNAc to the _6 Man (at the 2 position) of the trimannosyl core or 1 on the _3 and 2 on the _6 Man (at the 2 and 6 positions). Each antenna can be extended or capped with HexNAc, deoxyHex, Hex, or sialic acid residues.  [Essentials of Glycobiology:Glossary]
src_content.evidence: Increased expression of the high-mannose M6N2 and NeuAc3H3N3M3N2F tri-antennary N-glycans in cholangiocarcinoma.[PMID:29399163]

src_content.description: A glycan composed of three mannose residues, found as a modification on intracellular proteins in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

Truncated core 1 O-glycans are O-glycans based on the core 1 structure (Galβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr) that are incompletely extended. Examples include the Tn antigen (GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr) and the T antigen (Galβ1-3GalNAcα1-Ser/Thr), which represent early intermediates or incomplete forms of core 1 O-glycans.

Truncated N-glycans are N-linked glycans that are incompletely processed, often due to prolonged retention in the endoplasmic reticulum, resulting in shorter glycan chains than typically found in mature N-glycans.
O-glycans initiated by GalNAc on serine or threonine residues that are incompletely extended, including structures such as Tn, STn, and T antigens, which are often associated with cancer.

Truncated O-glycans are O-linked glycans that are not fully elongated or processed, often terminating in early core structures such as Tn antigen, T antigen, or their sialylated forms (STn, ST). These incompletely extended glycans frequently expose core structures and are commonly observed in carcinomas, where they can evoke immune responses.

A disaccharide motif consisting of galactose β1-3 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (Galβ1-3GlcNAc), known as the Type 1 chain. This structure can be repeated, serves as a scaffold for further glycan extension, and acts as a precursor for type 1 H and Lewis antigens.

The type-2 unit is a disaccharide motif consisting of galactose β1-4 linked to N-acetylglucosamine (Galβ1-4GlcNAc), which can be repeated and serves as a scaffold for further glycan extension. It acts as a minimal acceptor for glycosyltransferases, is a ligand for galectins, and forms the backbone for the synthesis of blood group H, A, B, and Lewis antigens.
A glycan chain present in human erythrocyte glycolipids that serves as the backbone for A, B, and H blood group determinants.

Xylan is a class of hemicellulosic polysaccharides composed mainly of linear β1-4-linked D-xylose residues. Commonly found in plant cell walls, especially in secondary cell walls, xylans may be substituted with other sugars or chemical groups and are important structural components in plants.

Xylogalacturonan is a class of plant cell wall pectic polysaccharides characterized by a homogalacturonan backbone with single β-D-xylose residues attached to the O-3 position of some galacturonic acid residues.

Xyloglucan is a major hemicellulosic polysaccharide found in plant cell walls, consisting of a β-1,4-glucan backbone substituted with α-D-xylose and sometimes other sugars. It plays a key role in cell wall structure and expansion by acting as a tether between cellulose microfibrils. Oligosaccharide fragments derived from the enzymatic or chemical breakdown of xyloglucan can trigger defense responses in plants and provide protection against pathogens.
Xylosides are glycosides in which xylose serves as the sugar moiety. They are used experimentally to prime the synthesis and secretion of glycosaminoglycan chains in cells.
Xylosylated glycans are glycans that contain xylose residues. These glycans may be attached to glycoproteins or glycolipids and are found in various organisms, including parasites.
A terminal N-acetylgalactosamine (GalNAc) residue linked via an alpha(1-3) glycosidic bond, as found in the A blood group antigen tetrasaccharide.
Branches in glycogen that consist of glucose units connected by α(1–6) glycosidic bonds, appearing periodically along the main α(1–4)-linked glucose chain.
A sialic acid residue linked in an α2-3 configuration that is present as part of a branched glycan structure, such as found on ganglioside GM2.
A disaccharide motif consisting of sialic acid linked α2-3 to lactosamine (Galβ1-4GlcNAc), commonly found in glycoproteins and glycolipids, and produced by group B streptococci.

The α-Gal epitope is a glycan determinant composed of galactose in an α-linkage. It is notably absent in humans and Old World primates, which results in the production of anti-α-Gal antibodies in these species.

src_content.definition: A glycosylgalactose that consists of β-D-galactose having an α-D-galactosyl residue at the 3-position.[CHEBI:62330]
src_content.evidence: Therefore, alpha-gal antigen might be eliminated after a prolonged culture, when using human cells.[PMID:31267683]

function.content: Has role as a carbohydrate allergen, epitope or an antigen.

src_content.description: A mannose residue attached through an alpha glycosidic bond, frequently found in diverse glycan structures and recognized by mannose-binding proteins.

A post-translational modification in which a fucose residue is attached through an alpha linkage to the oxygen atom of serine or threonine residues, most commonly found on epidermal growth factor (EGF) repeats.
A polymer of glucose residues linked by alpha glycosidic bonds, forming nanofilaments such as those observed in the mitochondrial dividing ring of certain algae.
A polysaccharide composed of a backbone of α1-6-linked mannose residues with α1-2-linked mannose side chains.
A glycan structure that contains at least one α-linked mannose residue, which is recognized as a pathogen-associated molecular pattern (PAMP) by immune receptors.
A glycosidic linkage where sialic acid is attached to another sugar through an alpha configuration.

β-(1,3)-glucan is a polysaccharide composed of glucose units linked by β-(1,3) glycosidic bonds. It can be linear or branched and is a major structural component of fungal and oomycete cell walls. β-(1,3)-glucan can also be released as oligosaccharides, which may function as pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) in plants.

A polysaccharide composed of glucose residues linked by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds; it is the main structural component of cellulose in plant cell walls. Oligosaccharides released from cellulose can act as signaling molecules in plants.

A polysaccharide or oligosaccharide unit composed of mannuronic acid residues linked by β-1,4-glycosidic bonds; these structures form part of alginate, a major component of some bacterial and algal extracellular matrices.
A homopolymer of mannose residues linked via β1-2 glycosidic bonds, characteristic of the mannogen polysaccharide produced by Leishmania parasites.

A structural motif where N-acetylglucosamine is linked via a beta-1,2-glycosidic bond, commonly found on the α1-3-mannose arm of N-glycans and known to influence fucosyltransferase substrate specificity.

A structural motif in which N-acetylgalactosamine is attached through a beta-1,4-glycosidic bond. This linkage is recognized as an antennal modification on N-glycans, such as those found in sea urchins.
A structural motif in which N-acetylglucosamine is attached via a beta-1,4-glycosidic bond, typically to mannose on N-glycans, forming the characteristic bisecting GlcNAc feature.

A β(1-6)-linked N-acetylglucosamine residue that is transferred by core 2 β1-6GlcNAcT enzymes (CGNT1, 3, and 4) during the biosynthesis of core 2 O-GalNAc glycans. This residue often serves as the branching point for poly-LacNAc extensions in mucin glycoproteins.
A glycoside in which a β-D-xylose residue is linked to an aglycone. β-D-xylosides can alter proteoglycan biosynthesis by serving as artificial primers for glycosaminoglycan chain initiation.

β-glucan refers to a class of polysaccharides made up of glucose monomers connected mainly by β-glycosidic bonds. These molecules are commonly found in the cell walls of fungi and plants, and they can exhibit structural diversity, including linear or mixed-linkage forms such as β-1,3 and β-1,4 linkages.
A galactose residue attached to another sugar or molecule via a β-glycosidic bond; commonly found as a terminal or internal residue in glycans recognized by galectins and other lectins.

A residue of 3-deoxy-D-manno-oct-2-ulosonic acid (Kdo) linked via a β-glycosidic bond, commonly found in the oligosaccharide portion of bacterial glycolipids, such as those present in E. coli capsular polysaccharides.

A glycan structure featuring an N-acetylgalactosamine residue linked through a beta-glycosidic bond. These structures can serve as primers for oligosaccharide chains on mucins and are known to inhibit O-glycosylation of glycoproteins.
A glycan structure containing an N-acetylglucosamine residue linked via a beta-glycosidic bond; it is found as an active glycoside in various oligosaccharides.

src_content.evidence: The alpha2-6-sialylated 6-sulfo-LacNAc determinant defined by the antibody was significantly expressed on a majority of normal human peripheral B-lymphocytes as well as follicular B-lymphocytes in peripheral lymph nodes.[PMID:17728258]

function.content: B-cell interaction with blood vessels and trafficking

src_content.evidence: The N-acetyllactosamine type 1 (LacNAc type 1, Galβ1,3GlcNAc) is a well-known precursor of several important blood group epitopes, such as Lewis A, Lewis B, or sialyl Lewis A [1], which are involved in many biological processes, e.g., fertilization [2] and pathogen adhesion [3]. [PMID:28796164]

src_content.definition: N-acetyllactosamine is a beta-D-galactopyranosyl-(1→4)-N-acetyl-D-glucosamine having beta-configuration at the reducing end anomeric centre. It is also known as galb1-4glcnacb or lacnac, belongs to the class of organic compounds known as acylaminosugars. These are organic compounds containing a sugar linked to a chain through N-acyl group. N-Acetyllactosamine is an extremely weak basic (essentially neutral) compound (based on its pKa). N-Acetyllactosamine exists in all living organisms, ranging from bacteria to humans.[CHEBI:16153,HMDB0001542]
src_content.evidence: Utilising a fast and sensitive screening method based on imidazolium-tagged probes, we report unprecedented reversible activity of bacterial beta1,4-galactosyltransferases to catalyse the transgalactosylation from lactose to N-acetylglucosamine to form N-acetyllactosamine in the presence of UDP.[PMID:31165848]

src_content.definition: (2S,4S,5R,6R)-2-[(2R,3S,4R,5R,6S)-3-[(2S,3R,4R,5R,6R)-3-Acetamido-4,5-dihydroxy-6-(hydroxymethyl)oxan-2-yl]oxy-5-hydroxy-2-(hydroxymethyl)-6-[(2R,3S,4R,5R,6R)-4,5,6-trihydroxy-2-(hydroxymethyl)oxan-3-yl]oxyoxan-4-yl]oxy-4-hydroxy-5-[(2-hydroxyacetyl)amino]-6-[(1R,2R)-1,2,3-trihydroxypropyl]oxane-2-carboxylic acid is a member of carbohydrates and carbohydrate derivatives.[CHEBI:151464]

src_content.definition: Type of N-linked glycan in which four antennae are present on the trimannosyl core, each initiated by GlcNAc additions catalyzed by position-specific N-acetylglucosaminyltransferases (GlcNAcTs). The four antennae are initiated by addition of 2 GlcNAcs to the _3 Man (at the 2 and 4 positions) and 2 GlcNAcs to the _6 Man (at the 2 and 6 positions) of the trimannosyl core. Each antenna can be extended or capped with HexNAc, deoxyHex, Hex, or sialic acid residues.  [Essentials of Glycobiology:Glossary]

src_content.definition: A complex N-glycan that has three branches attached to the non-reducing terminal Man residues of the trimannosyl core.[CHEBI:156252]  Each branch is initiated with a GlcNAc and can be exteneded or capped with HexNAc, deoxyHex, Hex, or sialic acid residues.
src_content.evidence: Fucosylated biantennary complex-type and small amounts (less than 5%) of triantennary complex-type structures were identified on the glycosylated asparagine residues using sequential exoglycosidase and endoglycosidase digestions combined with matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry (MALDI-MS).[PMID:9118998]
